content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												NOT A PRE-RELEASE REVIEWThis is one of my favorite alpha games ever to hit Steam.. And It's a damn shame I have to stomp it into the ground because during the estimated 1-2 years of work I expected this game to take before beginning to reach a finished state, the developers had a stroke of genius and decided that it would be a good idea to call this HEAVY ALPHA GAME a FULLY RELEASED TITLE after being on Steam for only 5-6 months. Doing so, Avalanche Studios have yet again showed the world that they do not give a damn about actually delivering a polished product to customers and fans alike and instead falsely advertise & release yet another unfinished glitch-fest onto Steam like a big, flaccid díck onto your dinner table, expecting a price-tag of 30€ for an experience you can expect out of a glitchy tech demo.I mean holy hell. They JUST spewed out a new dinosaur with this "release update".. AND IT HAS NO TESTING DONE TO IT WHATSOEVER. If you still insist on buying this garbage, kindly make note of the following issues the game currently has:------------------------------------------------------------------1. Animations for both dinosaurs and players are on a "Proof of Concept" level at most, and when combined with point 2, It makes for a disgusting game-play experience as far as immersion is concerned.2. The AI is absolutely atrocious. All dinosaurs can get extremely stuck on certain hills, get seizures or freeze up indefinitely if you decide to go up on a rock, the T-Rex can use you as a surf-board and stand ontop of you indefinitely without being able to attack if you go prone and have him not see and "aggro" you directly (Realistic, right?), The smallest of dinosaurs can take 10+ shotgun slugs to the head (and smash their skulls to thousand pieces) and still be alive & charge your person endlessly with no difficulty or signs of being stunned whatsoever, T-Rexes can with a 100% accuracy pinpoint your location If they hear you, say, walk at a steady pace 500 meters away, they WILL rush your location and insta-gib you unless you log out. Fun fun fun!3. The game has a disgusting lack of realism. Building on the previous statement of the dinosaurs having nonexistant AI in regards to stun or reactions overall, the game does not allow you to do VERY basic things like jumping while also having an absolutely broken "Hit-detection" system whereas you can know the exact angle and 3d space of say, a raptor's heart, shoot it with a shotgun slug.. And have the bullet either go through him completely, missing all organs or hit another bodypart. It's disgustingly random and sometimes, you can even get one-shot-kills without hitting any organs - and have no damage show up in the dino death re-cap window. There are also another giant design problem and that is the way that foilage works in this game. Dinosaurs do not say, leave grass bent or otherwise moved when they pass through it. It's like they're ghosts, so every time you chase or otherwise look for a dino where foilage is thick - you WILL NOT BE ABLE TO SEE IT. EVEN IF YOU KNOW IT'S RIGHT INFRONT OF YOU IN THE GRASS. It is one of these GIANT design issues that force you to avoid grassy areas all-together and it really brings light on how much of an alpha game this shít of a title really is.4. The game is very unoptimized. Most PC's struggle to run this game and while I didn't have any particular big problems myself, the forums speak for themselves though and following the numerous complaints I saw, I made a closer inspection and did infact see that my G-Card had a tendency to being extremely hot when playing.5. The developers do not take advice or read the forums. Ditto. It took them literally 3-4 months to notice a typo in the forum section called "Thoughts & Suggtesions" or something like that and that's just a depressing realization as there are literally hundreds of posts made - Not ONE of them has seen their ideas/suggestions been implemented into the game.6. There is legitimately no goal in this game. You roam around like an idiot (sometimes for a whole hour or more if you're unlucky), looking for dinosaurs with a shoddy bow and If you want to have different weapons, you HAVE TO <-- go to a pre-defined location and rummage through larger crates... Or die and go to the store that have rétárded level restrictions on all weapons & ammo that can sometimes require you to kill literally hundreds of dinos before having THE OPTION <-- to spend your own points to spawn with the gun you want next time you die. Crafting? End-game? Goals? Plot? Story? What's that?7. Sounds are downright broken and extremely confusing. Your own footsteps can make stomping noises with that of a T-Rex if you take small steps and listen carefully while certain raptors simply have no sounds to them at all except the standard "chop" attack bits while others have loud yelping calls, aggro noises, etc etc. While It certainly has jump-scared me a few times to get my buttocks suddenly chewed on by something that didn't make even the tiniest of noise, having some raptors suddenly become Batman in the Jungle while the rest are akin with that of howler monkeys is not a good as far as gameplay consistency is concerned.------------------------------------------------------------------Avoid this game and for the love of god, avoid the developers just as much. unless you enjoy being ripped off.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												===ANOTHER UPDATE===The birds are completely fixed now and no longer pick you up and drop you from a height and kill you. They'll only do that now when you're on low health so it's much better. The game has improved since my last update, the triceratops now act like rhinos instead of deer which is much better. ===UPDATE===They've updated the birds and the game is once again enjoyable as long as you stay away from the volcano (where the birds spawn). But I still stand by my comments about it not being a release spec game, this is still the quality of an early access game by far. ========================================REVIEW ON FIRST DAY OF RELEASE:In early access this game was brilliant. On release however, they added the new flying dino with a strange name which I can't remember... The new species has ruined the balance of the game, it'd been added with little to no thought whatsoever. It's a rushed release. In it's current state, I would not buy the game. I won't be playing it in it's current state either. The game used to be challenging but enjoyable, now it's overly challenging with you dying 10 times an hour and eventually rage quitting with nothing enjoyable about it. I'd rather take on a T-Rex than the over powered birds. With a T-Rex, you can hear it, you can see it coming, you have a chance. These birds, you'll probably shoot it once it'll grab you and drop you from a height and you die and there's nothing you can do about it. There are still crashes, tons of glitches, this is no where near a "release spec" game. Don't buy the game unless they've updated it and fixed the above.

Early Access Review
								In laymans terms, this game mixes the Carnivores experience with a survival aspect. I found myself listening very closely for cues about nearby dinosaurs, as well as looking for dangerous foliage. The sound in this game is so excellent, it's hard to describe in words. This is one of the few dinosaur games in a long time that feels 'serious', in my opinion. There are a fair share of bugs (rubberbanding dinosaurs, some collision issues), but for 85% of the game, you more than likely wont notice an issue. This game fills a void that I have been longing to satiate for years. Highly recommended!Check out the video for a hands-on look (no terrible BG music or lame voiceovers, I promise!)http://www.twitch.tv/gamethesison/b/599497190EDIT: I'll leave this anecdotal part here             5 minutes in, a Tyrannosaur charged me, drug me down a mountain, and feasted on my body. 10/10 would die again

content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												God d****t, god f*****g d****t it happened again.Another product not ready for release. D':[EDIT3]: I would like to update this review to address some of the points brought up by some reviewers who have thumbed up this game: 1) People who thumb down this game are little kids who just want call of duty can can't handle the difficulty of this game.  My response: Um, hello? Have you been playing this game?  It's seriously ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ly easy now.  I have no idea what you are talking about.  Yes, things used to be very dangerous, you used to have to actually hunt, but now you can just run full speed through the forest and if anything comes at you all you have to do is step to the side or next to a rock and because of the crappy pathing you can just blow anything away COD stye.  Let me just say for those that have not yet bought this game, anyone who makes this argument has no idea what they are talking about.  I mean seriously, there's one guy on here with like 500 hours on this game saying that . . . 500 ♥♥♥♥ing hours . . . 500 ♥♥♥♥ING HOURS! 500 ♥♥♥♥ING HOURS IN A ♥♥♥♥ING HALF BAKED EARLY ACCESS WITH 5 ♥♥♥♥ING DINOSAURS THAT PRETTY MUCH JUST RANDOMLY WALK AROUND!  500 ♥♥♥♥ING HOURS!!!! ARE YOU ♥♥♥♥ING KIDDING ME?!?!  I PLAYED THE♥♥♥♥♥♥OUT OF SKYRIM WITH LIKE A BILLION CHARACTERS, WEAPONS, QUESTS, ETC. AND I COULD ONLY DO 300 HOURS AND YOU'RE ♥♥♥♥ING TELLING ME YOU PUT IN 500 ♥♥♥♥ING HOURS WITH LIKE A FEW ♥♥♥♥ING  WEAPONS AND 5 ♥♥♥♥ING DINOSAURS THAT ALMOST DO ♥♥♥♥ING NOTHING.  This game is not ♥♥♥♥ing better than my beloved Skyrim.  Don't waste your money.2) Yeah they shouldn't have released this game and yeah they messed up on the release update but they are trying to fix it so everything will be ok.My response: I think you are delusional. :p  They are trying to fix the update because they haven't gotten any money because of all the negative reviews.  That is the only reason they have responded.  So let me explain what's really going on.  This is a cash grab.  The developers are trying to pull a fast one on us by making this very flashy appearing game that we have all been desiring for a long time, make it barely playable, release it as a full game, and rake in the doe as people buy this game thinking its something it's not.  They know exactly what they are doing and there will be nothing further added on to the game once they make it playable again after those f****** birds.  Furethermore, even if they fix the game from the update that's not the problem, the problem is that they are trying to rip us off by trying to make this whole debacule ok.  Well it's not ok babe.  So for those who haven't bought this yet, don't waste your money.Chasing the early access dragon never pays off; I swear I will never do early access again.[EDIT]:  I hope this is an April fools joke.[EDIT2]: Nope not an April fools joke. Also, this is not a pre-release review!I just don't understand, this game has so much potential, it is so awesome even when it was early access.  Why release it now when it clearly is alpha?So let me go through some of the clear issues real fast:1) As another review said, they just released a new dinosaur. . . untested. . .2) The entire island is made of predators (except the triceratops) . . .3) There are no interaction between dinosaurs (no t-rex eating raptors etc.)4) you can easily step to the side and are invulnerable to the raptors due to primitive pathing.5) AI in general is meh.  Dinosarus just walk around aimlessly until they sense a player and either run away or run towards them.  Sometimes you might be hunted by a raptor which is cool right up til you simply step to the side and blow him away cause he's a complete retard. 6) No real survival mechanics despite the claim in the discription.  As far as survival mechanics go, you just get weapons and shoot at poorly AI driven lizards.7) Sounds have no direction so you cannot tell where the dinosaurs are comming from.  You just know they are somewhere around you.8) Primitive hunting mechanics that are not explained at all.  There's cammo you can find but I'm not sure it actually does anything, nothing with smells as far as I can tell, and sounds are a factor but are prone to glitches.  A.k.a. it is impossible to hide from a T-Rex.  You can track dinosaurs and there is sign but it's obvious, takes no real effort, and your gps does all the work somehow for you.9) The characters look like ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ hipsters who have some fetish for taking weird selfies with whatever they've managed to kill on this island. DX  Makes me want to get eaten.10) There are so many things that obvously need to be put into the game for a full release but aren't its seriously depressing.  I mean this game could be good, like really really good.Basically I would recommend this game if and only if it was put back into early access and reasonably regular updates happened over the course of a year or two.  That is what we all expected and were happy with.  I mean seriously I'm perfectly fine with a game taking time to develop as long as reasonable progress is made.While this game has amazing potential, I cannot in good faith recommend it because it is alpha and should NOT be considered a full release.[EDIT]: And these god d**n birds have ruined everything.  Seriously I'm pretty sure this release is an early April fools joke because this is ridiculous.  I mean seriously unbelieveable.  If it is just a joke I will update this review to a recommend.[EDIT2]: Nope not April fools joke.  And you know what the worst part is?"We are satisfied with how the Early Access phase went, with comminuty's help we managed to develop and implement everything we planned and promised when we set off on this journey three and a half months ago - two new dinosaur species, PVP and team support, player XP, in-game currency and store, localization in 13 languages, two new weapons and lots of tweaks and fixes. "So comming strait from the Dev's mouth here's how all this went down:First they came to the community with a concept that seemed great.  Then in three + months they added "two new dinosaur species, PVP and team support, player XP, in-game currency and store, localization in 13 languages, two new weapons and lots of tweaks and fixes", said the game was done and decided to charge $30 instead of the early access $20 (so apparently according to the Devs what actually amounts to a tiny bit of content and basic functionality is worth $10 percopy in and of itself).Well let's just say you need to do a lot more than that to finish a game.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												****** DO NOT BUY THIS GAME ****** ****** DO NOT BUY THIS GAME ****** ****** DO NOT BUY THIS GAME ******This game is absolutley terrible, it is underdeveloped, unplanned and was obviously just a quick scheme to get some funds for the company. The IDEA for the game was good, and I really tied to like it, but the application was horrific (I'm listing 10 reasons below)1. They simply took the engine of the previous theHunter game and added a few dinosaurs, no improvements on the engine or any attempt to make the game actually exciting (So yes I'm saying 99% of the time the game is Very BORING).2. Your character can't carry more than 20KG, which is not nearly enough in comparison to the amount of bullets it takes to kill a single dinosaur (once I shot a triceretops with 23 bullets before it dropped, and that is only ONE dinosaur, it took me about week in real life to gather all those bullets). I managed to kill 2 T-rex's due to the Clipping bug where they got stuck in the wall. They either have to make the dinosaurs weaker, add more bullets, or add more backpack space.3. Your character dies 90% of the time with a single attack, a T-rex (one blow and you're dead), the Quetzalcoatlus picks you up and throws you down and you're dead, the Utahraptor comes in packs of 5 or 6 so unless you're carrying a vast amount of bullets, surving them is rather slim (but carrying a lot of bullets is also extremely unlikley since you have a 20KG limit)4. You start off with a machete, which does practically no damage at all. They wan't to give you the "feel" of a survival game, but no options to build a shelter or a place to store bullets and guns you've picked up (since you're sitting with limited space on you as a person), also no place to purchase more bullets once you run out.5. The game has a purchasing system where you get money for every kill (upon spawing ONLY), but you have to be an incredibly high level to be able to unlock decent guns, which is very stupid since you start off most of the time getting killed in the first 10 minutes (because you have no way to defend yourself properly).6. Running is a severe problem since the character is so slow, he only sprints for 100mtrs and takes forever to regenerate his stamina. Your character weights 60KG in the game and normally people that weight can sprint a LOT further since they have no extra body weight to carry.7. There are practically only carnivores in the game, which makes no sense at all (Apart from the triceretops). If there are only carnivores, what exactly do THEY eat? The had to add a lot more herbivores as well example: Galimimus (for the herd effect), Brachiosaurus (big game hunting), stegosaures etc.8. If it is supposed to be a hunting game, then your character must be able to look at tree bark to check for trails, you must be able to climb trees to be able to shoot the dinosaurs from above, little shelters close to watering holes. I honestly think the developers themselves never even went hunting once.9. As mentioned in section 2, dinosaurs have the capabilities to fly and travel through solid objects like rocks, but of course YOU dont. Your character cant even jump over small objects (since there is no such option), making climbing the volcano mountain in the middle of the map extremely tedious and it takes MUCH longer than what it would in real life (Also I think the developers never climbed a mountain in their lives either).10. The game (if you still want to call it that) is REALLY EXPENSIVE $29.99, with the same amount of money you can purchase much better games than this on Steam, since the developers aren't sure if they wanted to release a HUNTING game or a Survival game. So they took the worse out of both genres, added an insane price tag to it and sold it to the community. They ripped people off with theHunter, and now they're ripping people off with theHunter:PrimalI normally don't complain about bad purchases, but seriously DO NOT BE FOOLED BY THEIR MARKETING (as I was), rather spend your money on something else.****** DO NOT BUY THIS GAME ************ DO NOT BUY THIS GAME ************ DO NOT BUY THIS GAME ******

content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												The Hunter Primal. After reading dozens of reviews, and playing it for a few dozen hours myself I have come to some conclusions about the game. First off this is NOT a game for EVERYONE. Are you patient? This is arguably the most expensive tramping simulator out there... No kidding! There have been times when I've tramped for over an hour and not seen a Dino or anything of real interest except very beautiful scenery, but even that can get old. Or, you can load the game up and stumble across several T-Rex or half a dozen Raptors that tear you to shreds and cause you to lose all your gear that you've spent over ten hours collecting.A lot of people review the game negatively based upon the fact the game "isn't finished". The game is perfectly playable and enjoyable as it is, and is indeed "finished" it isn't however very "polished" and a few areas of the game could do with vast improvement, in fact a lot of areas could. If you need a slick, styled, polished game, this probably isn't for you. This game however is extremely immersive, and also very lonely. One of the great reasons for this game is the sense of abandonment, the aloneness, even with other players in the game. It's a harsh environment, there's big creatures out to kill and eat you, weapons are scarce and ammo is scarcer. It really does get the adrenaline going, which is a definite pro.Some say the game is easy, some say the game is hard. The game is both and neither. The difficulty is based on serveral variable factors, your skill at FPS, your gear (guns, ammo level, camo), your environment (jungle, plains, hills etc..), and the ammount and type of dinos around at the time. Sometimes it's near impossible to even stay alive, other times you're tramping around shooting things without a worry or care in the world. This is enjoyable as at times you can relax at times you need to focus more.All in all I enjoy this game very much, I wish there were more types of dinosaurs, and some parts were more polished but I very happily recommend it to people who fit the criteria above. Load up! Lets go hunting!

content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								I Alt-F4'd as a Tyrannosaur sprinted towards me.   


YouTube™ Video: My experience thus far [theHunter: Primal] 

			Views: 4,448		

			http://i.imgur.com/Z1RkYnh.png		

Full Review:Now that I have at least an hour under my belt, my initial impressions are as follows:Pros:1) Superb Sound design and stage. The forests and wildlife sound authentic, and the dinosaurs don't use recycled soundbytes from other games/movies.2) Graphical fidelity is great, but it's nothing to write home about. 3) The difficulty is refreshing and adds a feeling of helplessness as you're pursued by otherworldy creatures.4) Based on the developer's track record, this game won't be abandonded. I'm looking at you, The Stomping Land.Cons:1) It's immediately clear that this isn't a finished product and requires more content. In most instances the game will spawn you next to one of the three available dinosaurs, which loses its charm after being mauled several times.2) I haven't been able to host or join multiplayer sessions. This will most likely be patched within the coming days before Christmas.3) Key-Binding seems to be a bit unorthodox. I found myself rebinding most of the default keys to more comfortable orientations to suit my casual play-style. 4) Odd instances of AI-behavior and glitches. Despite being well-hidden, dinosaurs are inclined to walk directly towards you and into your line of sight; I also died in a pond reaching only my thighs.5) The Island is very large, but it still lacks a great deal of polish. More folliage and natural landscaping would do wonders for this game.Final thoughts: If you're thinking of picking up this game, wait until more content is introduced. Ultimately, I picked this up as a future investment, and because I just love me some dinah-saours. Consider this a future recommendation.

number of helpful: 281 of 374 people (75%) found this review helpful171 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												Me and this guy were walking around and saw a T-Rex, so we went prone. The giant god damn reptile walked right over us while we were laying there ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ our pants. When we thought we were safe, we slowly crawled away. After a few seconds passed, I heard a screen shaking, eardrum popping, massive sounding roar as I turned around to see my friend get devoured by a reptillian Satan. The beast then looked to me. We locked eyes for a moment, and a sense of understanding moved through me. It was then that the beast moved unto me, roared in my face, and ate me.10/10, would die again. But now for an actual review. After puting an extensive amount of time playing the game, I feel that I am ready to give a completely honest and full fledged review. This game, at its core, is very hit or miss. Some people will love it, while others will instantly denounce it for being too hard or a cash grab. While I believe the game is well worth the money, don't take my word for it. I will attempt to give the pros and cons of the game in a completely unbiased fashion, so that you may form your own opinion about the game before you buy it.PROS: 1. World and Atmosphere. This game couples amazing sound design with stunning visuals creates an amazing immersive world. You can hear T-Rexes stomping around from miles away, and spot Quezalcoatluses flying in the sky before they have a chance to see you. While this does add to the immersion, it also rewards attentive players who can see a threat before it even knows they exist.2. Weapons and Damage Models. The weapons of Primal are very grounded in reality. All weapons match to their respective ammunition types and every weapon looks, sounds, and feels like an actual weapon. Firearms are loud, bows have believable ballistics, and everything feels very solid. Coming from someone who is very experienced with firearms, I can attest to the realism of this game's weapons. Also, being based on a realistic hunting game, Primal's damage models are very precise. Heart shots are king, while general body/gut shots will not instantly drop most of Primal's beasts. Overall, the guns are good.3. The Actual Gameplay. Primal's gameplay is very intense, You can go from walking through a peaceful field to being chased by Utahraptors in mere seconds. This isn't a casual game. Deaths are punishing while kills are immensly rewarding. Even with high level gear, carelessness is often punished with death. CONS:1. Bugs. While the games stability has been immensely improved, the game still has lots of bugs. It wil crash every so often, and movement is very finicky. Also, the only servers are hosted through other player's internet connections, resulting in high pings and short lived servers. 2. Developement. Until recently, this game had been declared dead by most. The developers of this game are very invested in other projects and seem to view Primal of a sort of hobby on the side. On the up side, they have issued a survey for players to take and have also decided to try and tackle some of the bugs. Even though the game has officially released, they still intend on giving it regular updates.CONSENSUS: Primal is a great concept, but it is still in the making. While basic gameplay is good, there are still things that need to be ironed out and content that should be added in. While I understand some negative reviews, I believe that many of them portray this game in a bad light. Many people simply expect things from the game that it simply cannot offer. There isn't crafting or base building (as of yet) because the game is developed and marketed as a dinosaur hunting game. But, in the end, it is for you to decide. If you enjoy challenging or intense games, this is for you. If you're looking for another Primal Carnage of Orion: Prelude, then you will be dissapointed.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												Sorry to say, I'm very dissapointed with this game. I went in with high expectations, i mean after all, a survival game with Dinos? that sounds amazing! sad to say it was not. Mainly, there isn't enough content. I can't believe they would call this finished. There are none of your typical survival game aspects in here at all. No base building, trap building, crafting, hunger, nothing. You spend the whole game wandering this GIANT map, (which wouldnt be such an issue if you didnt walk slower than a crippled grandmother), trying to find supply boxes (which mind you, are NO WHERE near eachother) in order to defend yourself against near impossible to kill dinosaurs. Then, hopefully, if you manage to stay alive long enough, you can freely track and hunt the dinosaurs. Thats it. seriously, thats all. Not to mention there are only a grand total of 5 dinosaurs in the game. all of which are carnivores. (minus the Triceratops) and if you get spoted by a Utahraptor, you are pretty much screwed. you have limited defense, and you can't run very far or fast. Its irritating.The enviroment could use some cleaning up aswell. As much as they are beautiful, and perfect for screenshots and such, they aren't very functional for gameplay. most of the map has very steep hills, making it seem like the player shouldn't be there. Its very rocky, making it difficult to manuver. Most of the terrain is uneven, water clips through the beaches at places it shouldnt, the water randomly gets deep in some spots and seeing as you can't swim, also makes it hard to move across some beaches, and rivers/streams. Not to mention you can't jump. You also cant carry very much, which becomes problematic, if you cant store your ammo anywhere. Especially when you usually spend mostof the game with far more ammo than weapons. (and more ammo for weapons you dont have)Honestly, I'm very dissapointed. The idea for this game was great, but it's far from finished and is lacking severly in content. ESPECIALLY when they want $30 for it. dont waste the money.

Posted: December 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								Edit to precurser review: I would now recommend this game to anyone looking. While it is not all together in its current state, I have been in contact with the developers and they do have plans to continually update it with what the community wants. By purchasing this game, you show them that there is a market for it, and encourage them to better the game. Here is a video to show some gameplay mechanics.... Don't judge too hard, this was only my 3rd time playing 


YouTube™ Video: theHunter: Primal HD Gameplay 

			Views: 1,452		

			Hunt - Explore - Survive The most realistic prehistoric survival game ever created. Featuring a huge Jurassic environment populated by horrifying all-stars such as T-Rex, Triceratops, Utahraptor.		

Edit: Some more footage with the shotgun. Protip.... dont engage a T-Rex by yourself unless you have ungodly amounts of high powered ammo.


YouTube™ Video: theHunter: Primal Gameplay - T-Rex Hunt 

			Views: 254		

			Skip to 11:42 for action The Hunter becomes the Hunted - Part 1 - I found a shotgun and some slugs so I decided to go after the biggest beast in the game. It did not go so well as you will see.		

Pros: -Awesome sounds-Visually Stunning-Massive map-Stealth SystemCons-some of the weapons are underpowered (will explain later)-I have yet to kill a T-Rex. (May be a pro to some, but i put 8 slugs in ones heart/lung/brain.... plus 10 arrows in the lung region.... it should have died)-To many dinosaurs (wouldnt be a problem if you could actually kill them)-You move to slowly, and the stamina bar that allows you to run is depleted WAY to quickly, and recharges WAY to slowly. (seriously devs, go for a run, an average in-shape human can run alot farther than you imagine, and recover rather quickly)-Only 3 dinos (Im sure they plan on adding moreEdit: After playing this game for  nearly 6 hours now, I wanted to redo this review. I still find some of the weapons to be underpowered coming from a real life point of view. Both the slug shotgun, and magnum handgun should be much more powerful than they are, but they provide a fun challenge. The hitboxes on the dinosuars are still a bit off IMO, however once you get the learning curve, you can get it with a bit of luck. It is pretty fun to explore the island and try to hunt or avoid being seen. The graphics are beautiful, and ive found myself stopping several times to enjoy the view. If this game continues to be updated, it will be great by the time it reaches full rollout!Note for the devs:I found a few bugs so far I wanted to report-Tab doesnt always pull up pda-Rebalance gun damage-As long as a dino is behind you, it cannot hurt you-when you create a new game it is not truely new, it also doesnt spawn you with anything half the time-When you leave the game and come back, sometimes your secondary weapon is gone.As the game progresses and updates are made I will change my rating and review, I will also have gameplay video up shortly that I will link.Thanks for reading!Edit 12/16/14: The developer contacted me confirming they had recieved my feedback and would be implementing several parts.I will be changing my recommendation to a thumbs up once the first update is out. As long as the devs will listen to the community and continue to put out updates, I will reccomend it. As I continue to play it, I enjoy it more and more. Of it still isnt fully there, but it is an enjoyable time waster. As of now there really is no objective, Im hoping some objective will be added later. Also another thing that I have found to be annoying is the fact that you cant stack  items. If you find a pile of 2 arrows, and one of 3 you cannot combine them. Once again im sure this will be fixed later.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												Before we start, I want to be clear: You're enjoyment (and the relevance of this review) depends entirely on what you're expecting from TheHunter: Primal. If you are expecting a slow-burn, high tension survival title in an alien world of dinosaurs, you may garner a lot of enjoyment from this game.If you are expecting a immersive, realistic hunting simulator where you pursue and down the greatest creatures to ever walk the land, you will probably be disappointed.First, the positive: the game is beautiful. The textures are crisp. The dinosaurs are quite colourful and varied looking, yet still manage to blend in enough to require careful spotting. The plantlife is dense and oppressive. The weather is startling to see for the first time. The world is huge and packed with dense forests, open plains, beaches and swampland.The dinosaur damage model is highly detailed, with careful shot placement required to ensure that Utahraptor goes down in one shot, or at least bleeds out before it runs too far to track the body.The sound design is also well thought out, as careful listening is needed to pick up approaching predators and tell their mood.What are the major problems with this game? The largest (in my opinion) is the stamina and running mechanics. I mentioned this game is huge. It truly is, yet you walk with the speed and haste of a high-class Victorian lady visiting the Botanic Gardens on Sunday afternoon. The stamina bar is woefully low and is depleted in 10-15 seconds of running (the running too is far slower than any person with full use of their legs would manage when being pursued by hungry dinos). It refills much slower than it is consumed. I can understand wanting to discourage endless running over kilometres without breaking a sweat, but for the self-proclaimed "most realistic prehistoric survival game ever created", this is extremely tiresome, not to mention immersion breaking. It also makes no sense from a standpoint of offering a challenge to players: most everything can outrun you if it makes a beeline for you, and running already makes extra noise, so why bother adding ANOTHER impediment to your escape? It would have made more sense to add a general "exhaustion" meter that slowly increases the more you run, that slows machete swings and makes aiming more difficult as it fills.It also makes tracking wounded dinos a pain, as they will run far from your position in the time it takes them to bleed out. The choice of stamina bar clashes harshly with the wide open spaces and fast dinos around you, especially considering you are meant to be a fit, strong colonist capable of crafting machetes and bows from scrap.This brings me to the second major complaint: the predatory dinosaurs. The predators on this island are incredibly numerous, and VERY dangerous. This may sound exactly like a predatory dinosaur should be, but let me ellaborate. These creatures are determined to catch you. VERY determined. Too determined. T-rexs will more often than not just *happen* to wander in a straight line towards you, and once there refuse to leave until you move from hiding. Once again this would not be a problem if it were not for other choices made in development, such as the inability to run for any real length of time, and the limited weaponry or distractions. Just to reiterate, this helps makes the game stressful and tense, effective for survival gamers, but infuriating for hunting enthusiasts who simply want to grab a rifle and track down a triceratops.Other complaints involve the lack of swimming mechanics to allow lake crossings, or even crossing 10ft wide bays at the beach, the dinosaurs' stilted attack animations (that do fortunately make the machete a viable weapon against solitary raptors), and the absurdly high populations of predators. Arrows are also extremely difficult to track in flight, and hence getting a grip on the shooting mechanics is primarily trial and error (since you can't retrieve arrows from the ground you're discouraged from practicing shooting trees and stones). The predators themselves are too... predatory. Why is it the T-rex's will always go out of their way to catch a bite sized meal like me when a raptor just walked by them. Why can't they ever just not be hungry you know... LIKE REAL ANIMALS. In fact, other than apparently clearing out when a T-rex wanders their way, the other dinos don't come into ANY conflict with each other, limiting your strategies to deal with them.If the developers DID intend this to be a survival game primarily, then I'm baffled by the lack of food requirements (other than health regenerating eggs and mushrooms), proper shelter (other then some bare concrete walls to hide behind) or other survival staples. The only goals really are to go from landmark to landmark across open ground, avoid the overly numerous Tyrannosaurs, gather some ammo and hunt something for points, before lettting yourself die so you can use those points to buy a better weapon. Survival in this game is too often down to dumb luck. HOPEFULLY a T-rex won't march right up to you just as you got a .44 magnum with no bullets. HOPEFULLY a Quetzacoatls won't grab you as you're lining up a shot on a raptor and drop you 70ft to you're death. HOPEFULLY those raptors won't wander on top of your hiding spot.If what you were expecting was The Hunter with dinosaurs, where you choose from a variety of weapons a gadgets to track down elusive and deadly creatures in their natural habitat, then you'll probably be disappointed. I appreciate that Expansive Worlds wanted something different for this game. And there is still time to make a strong impression in future updates. But I feel that if they had simply ported the weapons and hunting mechanics from the Hunter, and made this current game mode optional, they would have made a stronger first impression.Too sum up: Buy if you want to crawl past huge predators, sneak around raptor packs and quietly through herds of triceratops with hair trigger tempers.Don't buy if you're looking for a hardcore hunting simulator where you can bring you're favourite mauser rifle to bag a velociraptor at 150m.To each their own I suppose.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												Update 4/11/2015:They did a MAJOR overhaul on the Quetzalcoatlus and it made the game A LOT more bearable. Quetzalcoatlus aren't EVERYWHERE now (they only spawn near Volcano's and really high lands). This alone made the game so much better. Now you can actually EXPLORE the land without definite insta-death.However, every other issue I've stated is still a thing.1) You rarely see dinosaurs in a game about dinosaurs.2) You travel for LOOOOONG lengths of time (up to 50mins) with absolutely nothing happening.3) Killing dinosaurs is nigh impossible at the start of the game (i.e. Levels 1 through 5-ish)4) If you haven't racked up a few kills for exp and money then good luck killing anything after an hour.Once you get to higher levels (9+) the game becomes a lot more tolerable; but from a gamer point of view: Why would I want to keep playing a game if the start of it is dreadful, boring, and hard (in the sense that you can't really kill anything)? I mean, yes, the survival aspect becomes fun once you're higher level; but with that promise, why would a person new to the game stick around long enough to sift through the bane of this game? I know I called the game "Garbage" in my original review; but it's not. What it is, is unbearable (at first). And you'll have to put up with that unbearable irritation for a long time because levels aren't easy to gain (since dinos are rare to come across). Once you get past that, however, you could potentially start to enjoy yourself.- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -Original Review: This game is a COMPLETE waste of money! Hear me out, because I keep coming back to this game, TRYING to like it, but it's terrible. And here's why:-There's NOTHING to do:You spend, I kid you not, 90%+ of this game walking around with absolutely NOTHING eventful happening. NOTHING in this world can really be interacted with except for loot crates and dinos. Your objective for most of the game, survuve. How are you gonna survive? Find camp points that have survival equipment (weapons, camo-clothing, healing supplies, etc). But the map is HUGE and that becomes obvious when you're walking with your GPS for 20 minutes and you've literally only traveled a distance about the size of 1/3 your pinky finger. None of these camps are anywhere NEAR close to each other, either; so if you're at a camp and you try to travel to the next closest one, be prepared to walk in a straight line for about 50 minutes, with NOTHING happening.-It's nearly impossible to kill dinosaurs in a game about KILLING DINOSAURS:Game Story - "You're a convict sent to a dino planet to kill as many dinos as possible to pave the future for potential civilizations." Early game, you MAY get lucky enough to find small Raptors. You can kill those with the machete that you get for free when you spawn, and that's where you get experience and money to buy things when you die and have to respawn anew. However, the dinosaurs age within game, and after 30 minutes they're fully grown (your gps tells you the age). Cool mechanic, BUT YOU CAN'T KILL THEM BY THAT POINT! Fighting baby Raptors is likely to yield success, BUT your health is gonna be dried up by that point, so you're going to eventually die. HOWEVER, the timer for the dinos doesn't reset! So now you have ADULT raptors, which you can't kill because as soon as you get close to killing them, they run away; and there is NO catching up to them. You can run, but your stamia is a handicap BEYOND BELIEF! You can track them with your GPS (via blood trail, foot tracks, dung, etc) but you'll be tracking for at least 20 minutes before you catch up to it. The dinos can bleed out and eventually die once you hit them; cool mechanic, HOWEVER, the time for that varies and the odds are, you WONT find the dino that you wounded; but if you do it'll be like I said before, "Tracking them for 20 minutes before you finally catch up". Mind you, this is just the case for the raptors, THE EASIEST THING TO KILL IN THE GAME!-Quetzalcoatlus... Quetzalcoatlus...If you can tolerate walking around doing nothing for 90% of the game, and don't mind the fact that after 30 minutes, you wont be able to kill dinosaurs anymore, then I present to you, the one dinosaur, that ruins this entire game. Quetzalcoatlus. This flying dinosaur is the ONE major flaw that was put into this boring, uneventful, over priced, waste of time game! Quetzalcoatlus flys down, picks you up, and carries you around for 10 (Mississippi) seconds. Then he drops you and you die... No questions about it. You WILL die when it drops you. I've survived drops twice (I don't know how) but then it circles around to finish the job... Quetzalcoatlus is the primary reason this game is absolute garbage. You think walking for 50 minutes to reach a camp and get its spoils finally pays off. Nope. Quetzalcoatlus are ALWAYS around these camps. You can go in and get the stuff, yeah, but Quetzalcoatlus WILL catch you while you try to leave, and it WILL kill you. When you die your body becomes a pack of bones that you can come back and loot for your old equipment; but of course Quetzalcoatlus will STILL be in the area; in fact, MORE Quetzalcoatlus will be in the area! Because it seems like every time you die to one, another one spawns in the area! Quetzalcoatlus are only a threat in open areas? Oh ok, so my options in this game are 1) Be safe from them while I walk around the forest areas where's there are no camps to get equipment, little hope of actually seeing a dinosaur, and just endless walking around with absolutely nothing else to do. or 2) Walk out to a camp in hopes of finding things to survive and die to Quetzalcoatlus, walk out into the open in hopes of exploring this huge world and die to Quetzalcoatlus, or try to walk from this forest to another forest and die to Quetzalcoatlus.-There are very few dinosaur sightings in a game about DINOSAURS!It's so rare to actually see a dinosaur in this horrible game. You'll find tracks and other signs of them in your area, but they're constantly moving, and they're faster than you and don't have STAMINA ISSUES! You will NOT see dinosaurs often. So you will not kill dinosaurs often. So you will not gain money or experience to buy things that will help you kill dinosaurs... which are rare to find in a game ABOUT dinosaurs! There is one dinosaur that you can easily find though. Quetzalcoatlus! Just look up into the sky and there he is! Walk out of the boring tree's and die! Or stay in the boring uneventful tree's and NOT die! GREAT GAME!

content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								Honest and non-misleading gameplay:


YouTube™ Video: theHunter: Primal - Starting Off! - Pt.1 

			Views: 3,000		

			Welcome to theHunter: Primal, a dinosaur hunting game, here we are introduced to the game, and test out our beginner skills.		

Comparing this to The Stomping Land and Beasts of Prey, this game easily beats both. When you enter this game you can instantly see a lot of work was put into it, with the huge highly detailed island, with the dinosaur models with textures done so well and the very nice ground vegetation which give the game such a great sense of realism. As a hunting game, the AI needs a lot of work, they are not buggy but rather dumb, like zombies in DayZ, and if they spot you they are close to impossible to kill, which in some cases can become frustrating. The mobile tracker device works perfectly, but I feel as if the original game deserves that credit.As a survival game I get a nice immersed horrified feeling, the aspects of this game can really come off quite scary, as the forest tried so hard to do.So far I can say that it is worth the money, the game shows hard work by the developers, and I have hope they can maintain creating a more realistic primal hunting game.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								As an expert in the field of paleontology I have a vast knowledge of dinosaurs, in particular the velociraptor; so therefore, I feel that I am in a strong position to express my thoughts on the hunting grounds of Primal Eden.I arrived on this planet having agreed to fly over it for a small fee as a tour guide (of some sort). At no point did I believe that these people were remotely crazy enough to land the plane. I woke up on an abandoned runway having been knocked out via a blow to the head. The distant sound of a man and woman shouting at the top of their voices filled my entire body with dread and fear as I came around. I knew this was now a fight for survival!As I moved swiftly and quietly through the thick, dense and foggy bush I hoped that I would find signs of life such as camps left over by previous people who dared venture to this ludicrous planet. Perhaps I could find some sort of radio or telephone that I could use to call for help. By now the valley around me filled with the unnerving sounds of various carnivores. The roars piercing my heart and sending tremors straight through my spine. There was no hope.As I laid helplessly in a thick set plant I felt the horrifying thud as the ground started to shake. I then realised it was the same terror I had experienced some years ago in Jurassic Park. The thunderous sound began to get louder and louder. I then ran as fast as my legs would allow over the valley hill and found an abandoned camp called Sir Arthur’s Folley. To my delight and amazement I found a .700 rifle and 2 bullets. I do not like guns but I intended to survive this island as I have done twice previously. As I loaded the bullets the tyrannosaurus rex came crashing through the trees behind me…...I knew what had to be done.I tried to throw a stone to distract the foul beast but to no avail. His head raised into the air as he then let of a rambunctious growl before charging at me. I immediately ran behind one the compounds concrete walls in fear of what was about to happen, with adrenaline pumping around my body I looked around the wall at the oncoming charge. I raised my rifle and shot the creature in the head! Nothing happened... I then ran back behind the wall where I realised my health was low from when I dropped down the small cliff into the camp. I sprayed myself with magic spray that made me feel revitalised and full of energy. The mighty head of the beast then clipped straight through the corner of the wall scaring the s**t out of me. “How the f**k can you do that” I angrily yelled at the beast. It then stood still so I took my shot, BANG, I hit the animal in the upper chest just below the neck. He let of an almighty howl as I punctured the left lung. As I aimed down the sight for one last time I pulled the trigger….nothing happened. I had no ammo.I then thought LEG IT, so I ran down the hill until my stamina had deserted me. I laid down in a bush hoping the foul creature had not seen me. My heart was thumping and sweat was pouring from my entire body. The footsteps crashed down the hill behind me. I laid there motionless. The T Rex then stopped not knowing where I was. I had done it, I had got away from the beast when I then heard footsteps to my left. I looked to find a guy in a bright yellow shirt and orange trousers standing in my bush. I then slowly looked around at the T Rex as he then spotted me, charged me and then ate me. NOOOOOOOOO! The guy in yellow and orange clothes then proceeded to steal my gear and disappear into the night.Hmmm, maybe I get into character a little too much when I play this game….It is an epic game especially when played with other people. Getting ambushed by raptors or five people running from two T Rex’s is sooo much fun! Awesome game that you must try.

												I want to start by saying that this game has a lot of potential. (im sure you heard that many times but trust me, this game has a LOT of potential) The biggest problem with the game right now isnt the lack of weapons or dinosaurs, its not even the horrible AI, the biggest problem right now is the fact that its no longer in alpha. By fully releasing the game the devs are saying "Yep, its done, no more updates." now, im hoping that I'm wrong and that the developers will continue to update the game (add new dinos, guns ect...) You see at the moment the game is only fun to play with others, you simply hunt dinos together, you'll enjoy that for an hour or two but you will eventually realize thatA) there is no goal, you just hunt. (there isnt a survival aspect to the game, you can just stay in a zone where dinos don't spawn, there is no reason to leave these zones.)B) there are only five dinos, and two of them are basically the same one. (smaller and bigger variants)C) The game is buggy, and obviously is still in alpha (even though the devs say otherwise)--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- You should only buy this game if the devs will keep updating it, if they'll keep adding new stuff, if they keep fixing the glitches. What you should do is watch the game, check the store page every now and then, if you see more (significant) updates then yes buy it. But at the moment it seems that its very likely that the devs will abandon this game.so....Q: SHOULD I BUY THE GAME???A: nope....not yet.

Early Access Review
								First time me and my friend played, we didn't fully grasp how the game was to be so difficult, and being the naive little insubordinates that we were, we skimmed through guides and just ignored them altogether (Which I wholeheartedly recommend.) After stumbling across the woods to find eachother, bows in hand, we set off to what we thought would be our opening into Dinosaur hunting greatness, and how we were oh so wrong. We had found our first Raptor, and immediatly started plunging arrow after arrow into the flesh of the Jurassic Park reject. We were able to wound it slightly, and it ran off. Thinking to ourselves "wow arrows suk lel" we journeyed off for awhile looking to find some better gear. Every step of the way, we heard noises from behind us, thinking nothing of it and brushing as local ambience, we sprinted ourselves deeper and deeper into our godforsaken fate. My friends going for a crate we found, I'm off looking around while he gets whatevers inside (prolly wasn't gunna share♥♥♥♥♥♥neither that cheeky♥♥♥♥♥ when out of the corner of my eye, I see something lunge out at me, and before I know it I'm dead and♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥that I lost my sandbox toy level equipment. My friends sneaking into some bushes trying to get a look at what killed me, and before he's ultimately assaulted from the rear, the last words in that foolish life were "He's got arrows all over him!"Hours later, we were molded by the forest, trained off of it and bred from it. No sound goes unnoticed, no footprint ignored. Each pack is avoided and a single raptor is taken down with as much precision and accuracey we could possibly muster up. We had become The Hunter at last, but even that wasn't enough to save us from death after death.so its p. cool n♥♥♥♥♥♥buy it

												I personally found this game fun initially.... however, I could not reccomend this game to anyone in it's current state.. last patch was 10 months after the last one (which basically added a few skins) and all it "patched" was 2 bugs.. There is miniscule to zero development in this game, whis is really sad, as this game had so much potential.. If you want to try it out, make sure you can get your money back... You should also punish bad developers in some way.. in this case perhaps withdraw their titles from Steam until you are satisfied that YOUR customers are happy...

Product received for free
												I really like the concept of the game. I've had and played this game since pre-release. It had so much potential. In its current state it is playable, but there are a lot of little bugs that will annoy you over time and you'll reach end game rather quickly with nothing else to motivate you to continue playing. The company behind the game is the main issue I have with the game and not the game concept itself. They are just not putting enough effort into keeping the game fresh and bug free. It's a real shame to see a good idea go to waste, but the company has a real bad track record for neglecting their other titles in similar fashions as they have with this one and being only motivated by money sadly. Now that they have people's money I don't honestly expect anything new (and not just some reskin or rehash) added to the game unless it costs extra and the only bug fixes I'd expect to ever see are ones that are gamebreaking but the little fine tuning ones like the multiplayer bugs will most likely never get fixed. I gave the game and the company a huge amount of time to prove me wrong, but sadly they haven't so now I don't have much hope that this game will ever reach its top potential. I have to vote negative on the game and not recommend it to others unless you're getting it free or as a gift. Just don't waste your money. It's pretty much a game that you'll play through completely once and never touch again as the replayability factor just isn't there. All I can hope for is at some point the company cleans up its act and comes back and actually cares about this game enough to take advantage of its full potential. If that ever does occur I will gladly change my review, but I'm not holding my breath at this point.

												edit: What you all have to realize is this is not this developers main project. Updates will be sparse at times. "10/10 like Dark Souls with Dinosaurs"- IGNWelcome to Primal Eden, where your♥♥♥♥♥♥gets shoved in faster than you can say "The hell just made that noise?".I've played theHunter since 2011, and knowing the Devs, and how they are, when I first saw this I thought it was a joke.I was really excited to see that it wasn't, and even more excited to see it was coming out not long after I read about it.It's pretty hard to get the hang of at first but you will get it eventually, before it got updated to you starting with 10 arrows, and it was 5, after figuring out the general anatomy of the raptors I could take down usually 3 before I ran out. I recommend playing with a group, as it helps tremendously. I have to say I'm not a fan of unreasonably hard games, this pushed it at first, but I just kinda pushed through it, and now enjoy how difficult it is. After killing 3 Rex's 2 Triceratops, and about 200 raptors, I can only see this better as time goes on.Now if you guys are weary of early access because of Dev's ditching projects, that is DEFINETLY not going to happen with this, The guys that work on theHunter are some of the best Dev's out there with communicating and listening to the community, theHunter came out in 2008 and is being continuously developed with most of the ideas coming from the community itself, as I'm sure will happen with this too. They only add new animals every few months or so to the original because it's a pretty niche market and not a whole lot of money comes in, which is also why they have the micro-transaction system the way it is. However, this game is getting a tremendous amount of attention from famous Youtuber's and being the fact that it's survival which is the "in" genre, I HIGHLY, HIGHLY recommend this game, as once you get passed the steep learning curve, it'll become one of the best games you've played in awhile. And like I previously stated, It's only going to get better from here.Now if you'll excuse me, this .700 isn't going to kill Prehistoric-Alien creatures itself.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												(sigh...) Lets be clear about this: I loved this game, I still do. But I cannot recommend this to anyone at all just because it is extremely unfinished. When the Pre-alpha started in December I had really high hopes for this game. But I quickly realized that a really buggy pre-alpha really hurt the publicity of this game, so much that I feared that this game would be scrapped. It seems as if my fears have come true. As a $30 dollar game it is alright. The objective of the game is to survive long enough so that you can gear up and hunt dinosaurs. It follows the basic structure of thehunter in that the OBJECTIVE is hunting. This confused allot of people at the beginning, they thought it was a DayZ with dino's which it is not. With a large Island and a 5 species of dinosaurs you can have alot of fun. Running from Raptors, hunting Triceratops, and teaming up to kill T-Rexes is essentially what you will be doing. Most of this game revolves around teamwork to take down the biggest and baddest of dinosaurs. This is really what made this game stand out. It fostered a teambuilding enviroment without holding your hand. But as with most pre-alpha's it had its downsides.It started with only 3 types of dinosaurs (which grew to 5 types) which really wasn't that great. The weapons were lacking, the AI was terrible and it was all around a buggy game. Over the past 3 months the developers had been working really hard to polish up the pre-alpha and so it seemed as if everything was going just fine. Alas that was not the case...Currently the game still feels like its stuck in pre-alpha, there are still bugs, a low amount of content, AI STILL SUCKS, there are only a few weapons in game, and in general it is unfinished all around. This really sucks as it had alot of potential to ge a GREAT game but in its current iteration I WOULD GIVE IT A 5/10 AT BEST. Will I still play it, Yeah. But I would not advise you to buy it. Hopefully the devs will continue to produce more content and this jewel of a game can be saved. If they do fix it I will revisit this revew but for now, save your money and buy any of the other great indie games out there. It will be a much better use of your time and money.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												A game that showed a lot of promise during the Early Access days and had the potential to become one of the best, most immersive and most realistic hunting simulators, in the end failed horribly to deliver. What we have now is a game with minimal content, barely acceptable for a "full release", while ridden with so many bugs and glitches that they alone could easily ruin the experience for many. In the end, it somehow managed to become a game that was much better and a lot more fun to play during its Early Access days and as long as the developing team refuses to care, fix problems and add new content, even as DLC, I personally wish it could revert to that.Positive: + Large map, beautiful environment, realistic landscape + Good atmosphere, ambient sounds, day-night cycle and weather effects + The game gives a nice initial feeling and the first few times you get approached by a T-Rex can be pretty thrilling, but it gets old fast + Controls when trying to aim are clunky, but that actually adds to the realism + For a hunting simulator, I suppose it has a good variety of weaponsNegative: - The island may look beautiful at first, but once you've walked all over the map once, it all feels the same - Camouflage used to matter during Early Access, now it's irrelevant. Hiding prone and motionless under bushes saved your life more than often back then, now most of the time it makes no difference - Dinosaur AI, especially that of the T-Rex, has gotten worse and worse over the course of development. The T-Rex used to behave like a clueless animal when shot out of the blue, now it instantly locates your position and runs to you in a straight line, like a heat-seeking missile, stops and eats you without even wasting a second to look around for you. It doesn't get more unrealistic than that as in actuality, most of the time the animal wouldn't even be able to identify which direction it got wounded from - Only five species, two of which share the same model in different scales - All five species are aggressive, four of them being actual predators, the opposite of what you'd expect from a hunting session - On top of that, supplies and ammunition are so scarce that it feels a lot more like a survival game than a hunting game. Hence why I always called it "theHunted: Primal". The player is clearly the prey in this one - The dinosaurs never eat, drink, sleep or interact with each other, killing the realism - Hitboxes are and have always been a mess - Dinosaurs may still attack you through concrete walls and thick trees, one of the major glitches that was addressed countless times but was never fixed - Server issues and reports from players losing their entire inventories or never receiving the items purchased from the in-game after-death store are more frequent than one could imagineBorderline Ridiculous: ... You can carry about 18 bullets for the .50 sniper rifle when you are in your underwear, but you can only carry about 15-16 if you put on pants and a shirt. Even less if you put on sunglasses and a hat! ... The character runs out of stamina after sprinting for a few dozen meters, while the dinosaurs can sprint to the ends of eternity without pause ... The character also has some sort of mental deficiency, as he/she suddenly becomes unable to throw a rock while crouching on one knee ... Watching a T-Rex walking up an almost vertical hillside practically defies descriptionConclusion: Bugs, glitches and lack of content aside, it may be worth the purchase for its current price of €10 if you don't expect to be amazed, if you are curious and if you don't mind the expense and the indifference of the creators, as it will probably offer some good times, but let me remind you that the game cost €20 during Early Access. That alone says a lot.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												So I’ve noticed that this game has mixed reviews, most of the negative ones being written by people who have played it for a couple of hours and have been eaten alive, chewed up and spat back out only to be able to write  “this game sucks”. Well my fellow steamers, you are in luck! You’re about to get a summary from someone who’s played the game for 87 hours.I did write a ton about thehunter: Primal, but figured who will want to read a review the same size as The Wall the Nights Watch guard? So I’ve kindly summarised it.•	thehunter: Primal is an online hunting survival game. •	There are 5 different types of dinosaur, •	11 different weapons and many items. •	There is a shop where you can use in-game currency to buy weapons and items however you need to unlock them by levelling up. (It is not a P2W game)•	Everything wants to kill you. •	Hunting is similar to thehunter, you need to shoot the dinosaurs in the right place. But as the dinosaurs are usually trying to find you, you come across them more often.•	It is hard and challenging, but you get used to it once you've played for a few hours.•	There are no 24/7 servers and setting up your own can be difficult as you have to open ports.•	You can be a lone wolf or chose to band together with friends or you can try to make friends. However if playing the PVP mode, only team up with people you trust, as it’s a dog eat dog world out there.Pros•	It’s hard to play, but rewarding when you do well.•	Great game to play with friends.•	Very big map. •	PVP is fun.•	Levelling up system.•	In-game shop.•	Updated by devs.•	At moments you are terrified.•	Nice to hunt and be hunted. •	Day and Night.•	You get immersed in the world.•	Great dinosaur behaviour.Cons•	It’s hard to play, and annoying when you die a lot.•	PVP can be brutal.•	No 24/7 Severs and setting up your own can be a pain as you have to open ports.•	Render distance is similar to thehunter so dinosaurs/humans disappear when they get too far (however they have to be quite far to disappear.)•	Hit points on humans need to improve.•	Levelling up system needs something to show hunters how close they are to the next level.•	Transition from night to day needs to improve.If you like to be challenged then this is a good game for you, especially the PVP. Hunting dinosaurs is really exciting and something cool is always happening in the game. This is the kind of thing you will expect:You’ve been tracking a Triceratops you shot for the last 10 minutes, and you’re lead into a forest. Suddenly you hear raptors communicating with each other, then silence and a rush of footsteps. Screams from the U-Raptors fill your ears and you and your hunting party start manically firing at 5 U-Raptors ambushing you.Whilst PVPing you're making your way up the volcano with your hunting party and are hounded by the flying Quetzalcoatlus,  one of your party is caught by the Quetzalcoatlus and he’s flown into the sky and then dropped to his death. But the rest of you manage to make it to the base at the top. However a rival hunting party is already there and a fire fight ensues. Your team get mascaraed and you lose all your stuff.   Or you’re walking through the open plains and start hearing thud after thud and the ground begins to shake, you realise a T-Rex is coming for you and all you can do is run. But remember you have a high calibre weapon so try to take it on. You begin shooting at it and its getting closer and closer, just as it’s about to rip you to pieces you see an opening to its heart and shoot your .700, killing it instantly.

Posted: December 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								So, Primal. What can I say about Primal. Well in what other games are you forced to hide in a bush for half an hour with you buddy, whilst cowering from a T Rex? Honestly though, quite a good game, ill go over some pros and cons. Good: The atmospheric nature of the game is great; both the sounds and graphics are quite pretty. The core game play is actually pretty nailed down despite it being early access, you can shoot Dinosaurs and throw rocks and what ever, what more do you need?Despite there being little in game right now, it's actually quite fun grouping up with your buddies and treking through the jungle, surviving and all that jazz. Bad: The game lacks some content, I mean, we could do with some more guns, maybe some dynamic events. Base building would be great in this game. Then again, early access so what ever, no big deal. Run speed at the current gesture comes in two catagories: Faster than light or extremely slow. It would be nice to get a happy medium. The lobby/hosting needs some work. The Dinosaurs can be quite stupid sometimes, then again, they had small brains right?All in all, I reccomend this game, especially if you want to waste £15 and possibily have some fun doing it. I mean, its not the greatest game in the world, you'll find out how much patience you have and you will be in a bush for 80% of your game time, but even that being said, it's oddly addictive and way more fun with others.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												Updated April 1st Release:This is NOT a full release of a game.  It should be labeled as being in BETA at best.  Models and environment are top-notch.  Dino attacks still need some serious work.  Simple things like a drag-and-drop inventory aren't finished yet.  And most of all there's still no realistic interaction between the dinos, i.e. dinos preying on other dinos.  But its a lot better than it was.  It's getting there.  It has SO MUCH potential.This may be one of my all-time favorite games. But its not for everyone. It's like being a cop, I suspect. A midget cop in a barbarian cannibal universe. Armed with a big ♥♥♥♥ing gun. That you don't always have ammo for. So you hide in a trash can and watch them eat your friends and neighbors and wait for them to leave. So you can get the ammo left on their fly-blown corpses. So you can track those barbarian cannibals down and explode their livers. Then you take selfies with their dead bodies.Early Release Review:I will say up front that this is a hunting game.  You can spend a lot of time where nothing happens.  Ammo can be feast or famine, as it should be in a survival game.  The game pays off for those with patience and persistence.  You can sprint around so long as you hear nothing.  When you hear raptors, you have to slow down.  Move away.  "Make like a hole in the water."  Despite its myriad of disastrous alpha bugs and severe lack of content, I LOVE this game.  The environment is best I've ever seen.  There's a real feeling of terror when you hear a pack of raptors and have 2 shells left.  Or you're solo armed modestly with a Tyrannosaur  20m that has your scent.  Surviving encounters like this and the eventual vengeance exacted through patience and planning is exhilarating.  Teaming up and taking down a T-rex is fantastic fun. Beginning tips:  Weapons are at the settlements.  Download a basic map that shows the settlement locs and you'll have a gun in no time.  Ammo is found randomly in the wild.  Then find someone you can tag along with and work with them to get camo and ammo.  Once you've done this, the game really opens up for you.  Shoot for the heart/lungs/spine.  With the bow, don't wait for them to get right up on you.  Work for a clean LOS to the target and reveal yourself at > 10 meters so they come straight at you, exposing their chest for a killshot.

Posted: December 23, 2015
												I recommend this game, but with severe reservation. I have played this game a decent amount alone, with friends, and have made friends whilst playing it. The atmosphere is gorgeous, the dinosaurs terrifying at every point in the game no matter what items you have, and a game that works so incredibly well with teamwork. The issue: Development hit a extremely hard wall to the point it was "released" even when incomplete. This angered me that, with still so many issues and room for so much to be added, it was abandoned and left behind. From there I moved to ARK Survival Evolved and havent regretted it, looking back on theHunter: Primal with some friends, I regret that development stopped.Honestly this was one of my favorite games to ever come out on account of how terrifying and realistic it can become when trying to survive. They say it is a hunting game, but they fail to hint you that you are the one being hunted.So should you buy this game? Depends. Are you okay with a noncomplete game that has development seemingly halted at the moment? If so, and you love being terrified by the footsteps of T-Rex's and the screeches of raptors, then this game is for you. I'd give it a 10/10 for memories and content, but a 6/10 for developer involvement.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2016
												I really wish I could give this game a good review. It's a hunting game. With DINOSAURS. Who couldn't love that?Well, how about bugs? Do you love those? Because that should be this game's actual subtitle. TheHunter: Insects Flying Right at Your Face.The bugs are appalling and abundant. I'd say you lose one out of every five trophies to a bug these days. There's tons more bugs too - getting stuck in death state, server crashing when you come back alive to get your stuff, rexes sometimes don't come off aggro when you die and start running in a straight line towards where you respawned to kill you AGAIN (hilarious to watch when you're not being chased!), animals get stuck on terrain constantly, and half the time the game server is down so you can't play. People are also leaving after the last update, I've noticed. After almost a year of silence, the devs returned with the shortest patch notes known to mankind, and now the servers are down AGAIN thirteen days later. And the fixes they did implement? "Bug fixes" which no one has really noticed, and they fixed the system saving negative numbers (for cheat reasons.) Meanwhile, they just introduced a huge new map and several new animals on their pay-to-actually-play sister game.If you don't take your game seriously, your players won't either, so of COURSE they're gonna cheat! The game itself is poorly balanced between how much is in the game, how much ammo you need to bring down a dinosaur, and how much you can carry. You're not hunting dinosaurs, you're hunting ammo. Always. Hunting. For ammo.The dinosaurs themselves are actually pretty well-modeled and animated. I love the textures as well. The rex is legitimately terrifying when you see it and you're not prepared. Usually you can tell where they are because they're loud, but I've had several sneak up and eat me without a sound (bug?) which doesn't seem fair. The trikes provide a nice challenge. I'd really like to see some more dinosaurs though. Three predators, an herbivore, and a flyer isn't much. Why not some more herbivores, like a real ecosystem would work? The Queen is a rewarding challenge, though. Too bad even if you do 80% of the damage, the kill is still awarded to whoever fired the last shot, even if they're shooting a puny .44 or just a ramshackle bow and did 1% damage.Don't support devs abandoning their games. Don't support buggy, poorly balanced games. If you're dying for a good dinosaur game, this one at least runs better than Ark and is a more fun and rewarding challenge than The Isle, so for $10 you get what you pay for. It's cool for the first few hours, trying to level, trying to find weapons and ammo and you'll die a few times. You think it'll get more fun when you're a higher level, maybe, or they'll be some perks. Barely. Not anything you couldn't just find in a box elsewhere on the map.3/10 Still runs smoother than Ark. Most of my reviews include better alternatives to the games. In this case, an all-around better game is Carnivores: Dinosaur Hunter Reborn. It has parasaurolophus, triceratops, ankylosaurus, stegosaurus, gallimimus, ceratosaurus, tyrannosaurus, pterosaurs, multiple maps at visibly different settings, you can jump right in and hunt, there's fewer bugs (but then again, a restaurant in Detroit has fewer bugs than this game) and the dinosaurs are MASSIVE, as they would actually be. It really does feel like hunting giants. This? This is a great idea done spectacularly, spectacularly poorly. If the devs would pay theHunter: Primal a quarter of the attention that the REAL moneymaker (see: the more expensive) game gets, there would be a tiny fraction of the bugs and there would be more positive reviews. I sincerely hope the developers bother to read these reviews, but based on their maintenance on the game, I very much doubt it. So this review is to you, the consumer. DON'T BUY THIS. Don't support the neglect of games. Don't support buggy games with no fix in sight. And don't support shoddy business practices, like putting out a game to grab money and then walking out, only to return sporadically once a year to say a couple words and leave again. They're game developers, not my dad - we have a higher standard of them than that, and your money is better than that.You should take your $10 and instead use it to go buy yourself lunch. More love went into your McDonald's meal than goes into this game.I bought this game when it first came out. For $20. They have since dropped the price. Gee, I wonder why.
