content:
Posted: August 1, 2016
												A lot of people have criticized this game for being slow-paced and having only a small selection of dinosaurs to hunt.  I think it's because a lot of folks purchased this game expecting it to be like Turok - a fast paced, blood-soaked, action-shooter.  But this game plays a lot more like an open-world Resident Evil/Don't Starve with dinosaurs.  This game is about tension, about patience, and about getting scared out of your pants.  The open-world is gorgeous, and unlike most open-world games, this one seems empty - just as a real wild area would feel.  This means when you find a dinosaur or, more likely, groups of them, the impact on you and your choices and gameplay is enormous.  And having only a few species in any one area is more "realistic" anyway, a small island can't support big populations.  Each dinosaur species requires completely unique strategies and tactics to take it down, and will hunt (or not hunt) you in completely different ways.  That's much more enriching than having 500 monsters who all just bum-rush you and just need a headshot to kill them.  Yawn.The first time you're staring at a treeline and see a pack of raptors melt out of the shadows and start stalking across the open plains, or are cresting a ridgeline and see, in the distance, a huge tyrannosaur wandering along the ridge toward you, silhouetted against the starlit sky, and you start praying to anyone who's listening that it goes the other way and never finds you. . . you'll be hooked, I promise.I won't lie, this game is *rough*. It definitely feels like an indie game, the controls can be a bit buggy, and the AI oscillates wildly from being unutterably brilliant to "that raptor keeps running into that tree".  But in terms of pure, emotional turmoil and painting a picture of constant tension and subtle, creeping terror I've simply never ever seen in a game before, Hunter Primal is worth a shot.  So, pick this up if you want a deep adrenaline rush.  Don't pick it up if you want Call of Duty with dinosaurs.  Simple as that.P.S. This game gives me nightmares about being hunted by dinosaurs.  That's how well it's crafted to get at your mammalian prey-instincts!

												I don't like leaving negative reviews, but this time, I have to. I bought this game when it was still in Early Access because I really liked the concept of playing TheHunter with dinos. I stopped playing because the game was full of bugs and really boring. I've tried to play it again a few days ago, and it still is, even if they added new dinos and got rid of annoying things. They tried to make something between a hunting game and a survival game. I would have loved this. Problem is : It's neither. It's not a hunting game, because you have to spend a lot of time gathering ♥♥♥♥♥ons of weapons and ammo before being able to kill anything, especially if you have to track a wounded " Big " dino ( Triceratops or T-Rex ), because you'll probably be attacked while doing so and you have to be able to defend yourself. It's not a survival game because it has nothing of a survival except the " Everything will try to kill you " concept. You can't build a base, you can't craft items, you don't have to eat/drink/sleep...So, you just walk around for hours and hours, try to gather weapons and enough ammo and hope not to see a single dino before you have enough things to be able to defend yourself. It can take a lot of time, because weapons and ammo spawn randomly in boxes far from each other, and your character is f*cking slow ( Plus you can't really run because you don't want to alert dinos anyway ).This game has potential, but at this moment, it's just boring...

number of helpful: 66 of 101 people (65%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												Let me start by saying that theHunter: Primal has a lot of potential to be a great game.I'm a huge fan of the original "theHunter", and have been playing it for at least 5 years now. Still play it quite often to this day.I was always a fan of hunting games (Deer Hunter 2005, was amazing), and dinosaur games (Many hours were spent playing the Carnivores series of games, even the broken JP: Trespasser and Turok), so when I heard about theHunter:Primal, I was stoked to say the least.Before purchasing this game I had high hopes of it basically being a clone of the original game, replacing the local fauna from our time period with the prehistoric variety, while keeping the same solid, fun gameplay that has made theHunter so popular since it's release quite a few years ago.What I got feels like an extremely rushed, unfinished, buggy "game" that still feels like it's in an early alpha state.I can't stress this enough: THIS GAME DOES NOT FEEL FINISHED.The animations are for the most part awful. Don't get me wrong; when the dinosaurs aren't walking or anything they look very nice, and as realistic as anyone could expect from species that have been extinct for millions of years. But as soon as they start to walk/run, that's where the animations all go to hell. I've seen triceratops doing backflips trying to walk up hills, Dissappearing right infront of your eyes, and then magically reappearing a few hunded feet away.I've had Tyrannosaurs walk right up to me and stumble around me in circles before walking away, and when they get 100 feet or so away from me, suddenly realize I'm there, and then eat me (I was walking around while standing up this entire time).I've 1-hit-killed a Utah Raptor with a makeshift bow, while I was unable to drop a Triceratops by putting 6x 12guage slugs into it point blank, among others.Another problem I have with this "game" is where in the original, you would spot lots of animal tracks, etc. Making it fun to stalk whichever animal you were following. In Primal, any sort of tracks or sign seem to be very few, and far between. I've followed a Triceratops as it stomps through the river banks for about 20 minutes, all while not leaving a single track. How are you supposed to hunt in this "hunting game" if there are no tracks or sign to go by?Also, why did they feel the need to make this a survival style game, where you spend most of your time wandering around aimlessly trying to find a weapon powerful enough to even kill a raptor the size of a turkey?I'd be much happier if they went with the same hunting mechanic as the original where you pick your weapon loadout at the lodge before you head out.  I know they basically replaced the lodge with the drop ships, but the fact that you need to earn so many credits for even a basic weapon, makes this game ridiculously tedious, and hard to enjoy.You should start the game with at least a capable rifle, and then scavenge/buy more ammo as you need it. Sure, have the player able to find new weapons in crates still, but at least give them a capable weapon to start with so they can enjoy the game. I didn't buy a hunting game to "survive", I bought it so I could hunt dinosaurs. And if I were going to hunt dinosaurs in real life, you can be damn sure I'd be taking a rifle with me from the get-go.Another small issue that needs to be fixed is the weird "wave-splashing" effect, that seems to come out of the ground or in the middle of a lake. I think the water would look much better if that effect was just scrapped completely.The flora in this game also doesn't seem to be nearly as convincing as it is in the original theHunter game. I'm not sure what it is about it, but it just doesn't look as good as the original. I love the look of the forests in the original game. The jungles in Primal, not so much.Also, the sound is a big issue with me. In the original "theHunter", the sound has it's issues, sure (mainly just the fact that footsteps would sound like they're on top of you, even though they could be 100 yards away), but for the most part. "theHunter" sounds beautiful, the entire time you're playing.In Primal, the sounds in the forests/jungle aren't anywhere near as immersive, and it also suffers from the same "close-sounding" footsteps problem. Also, some of the sounds are just strange. I'm not sure if it's just Utah Raptors, or all (I think there's like five...) of the species, but there's always this strange "dragging" sound when one is close, and I have no idea what that sound is supposed to represent, but it just sounds awful, and not natural at all.I've also encountered quite a few areas where there is a beeping sound as if I'm close to a supply crate, but there is nothing to be found. So after searching the area for a while to see if there is a "hidden" crate, I just give up, and leave. This has happened in quite a few areas for me.Now, I don't want to sound like I'm completely bashing this game, because I really want it to succed. I just feel that there's no way they should have let it out of early access in the current state it's in, and they definitely shouldn't have called it a full release. It's not even in beta state in my opinion. They should have spent at least another 6-8 months on it, and ironed out the bugs at least, before releasing it. And that's not including all of the gameplay issues I have with this game.I wouldn't recommend buying this game yet, wait for them to (hopefully) release some major patches for it, to bring it closer to something that feels like an actual game, and not a tech demo. I'm glad they didn't go with the subscription price model like the original (Although I'm guessing that's the only thing that's kept the project alive for so long, otherwise they'd have no incentive to keep updating it), but I fear this "game" is going to become filled with microtransactions to bring it up to the caliber of hunting simulation it's predecessor is.

content:
Posted: January 18
												This game... I don't even know where to begin, honestly. When this game first came out in beta, it was absolutely amazing. Sure, there were bugs and it felt slightly empty, but it showed promise and was a hunting simulator for DINOSAURS. Now when I say hunting simulator, I'm not talking about some new age Cabela's game where the whole goal is to track deer to a preset location for a monster buck with the same score in every disc and every playthrough. No, this game was unique. Everything was different, dinosaurs were rather rare and so it made the hunting aspect so much more enjoyable. For an early access game, i expected nothing less from the makers of TheHunter. Let's flash forward a bit now. The game was released fully with like three to four more primary additions from early access. That' it. Since then, there has been minimal contact from the developers, the bugs still persist, and anger and disappointment still exist in the community. This game was, from the start, only meant to be an extremely minor side project for the some of the developers at Avalanche. What said developers do not seem to grasp is that this game caters to a whole different demographic of people, which for some reason doesn't seem to interest the marketing department of this company at all. So, ultimately, it seems as though Avalanche only gives a damn about two game frachises: The original "TheHunter" and "Just Cause". Any others are pretty much trash, with the only attention it deserves is to pick it up off the floor. I am extremely disappointed in the state of this game and from what I can tell, its not going to get better. I will still play this game, (at least if a new patch comes out which reenables my ability to actually start it without freezing pre-title screen), but ultimately, its not worth the $10 to purchase. I regret having made my purchase in the past, but i have had fun on it with my friends.TL;DRDon't buy it unless it starts selling for like $5. The game isn't worth it.It's buggy, empty, and pitiful.So much wasted energy on a potentially amazing game from a company who doesn't give a damn about its fans unless they play "TheHunter" and pay a subscription.

number of helpful: 28 of 38 people (74%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								I guess I'll write a few things about the game. TL:DR version at bottom, even that is long.First things first, this is an EA release which means its full of issues and is incomplete as far as content goes. Visually it looks very good, and the sounds are good though there are a few glitches, especially when standing near someone who is trigger happy, or about to be eaten.  The issues I have no doubt will be ironed out but their release target of early March 2015 is rapidly approaching.  And as far as content, if this game ends up getting the same kind of attention to updates and additions as theHunter has, then we will not be wanting for different critters to hunt, or varying types of gear.As far as the gameplay goes this is one of the most fun games I've played in quite a while, and doubly so when playing with friends. And you do need to play with some friends or at least make some and travel around in a group, as your suvival chances are very slim with no allies.  The only thing that becomes an issue when in a large group is ammunition, as there is usually a shortage for everyone, not like that is better for solo players however.The problem here lies in the loot tables, or rather the amount of loot/ammo whatever that shows up in each box. The boxes need to have at least double the ammo available if not more, and there really is no point in having a stack of 1 round that you cannot merge into other stacks, same with healing sprays.(Fixed! You can now stack ammo and stuff, GJ Devs!) Players shold be able to jump, and possibly climb low walls and rocks.And lastly, as with theHunter, there really needs to be dedicated servers for this game, as the host/client connection issues that plague theHunter are present in this game, with players timing out or crashing every few minutes, it can become frustrating just to play for a few hours.TL;DR versionPros- Amazingly fun with a group.Good visuals, some of the scenery is quite beautiful.Good sound, the sound of a T-Rex stomping near me makes my whole house shake with the sound turned up!Great potentialCons-Incredibly high learning curve.Exceptionally difficult almost futile to play solo, turning some gamers away, and others to hacking/exploits.Obvious glitches and bugs that would cripple a live release (I expect they will fix this by release)No Dedicated Servers, and with the crappy hosting/client system this will keep many players from fully experiencing the game.Tiny pool of creatures to hunt (Obvious that more will be added)Small pool of weapons (also expect this to change soon; WTF no .50 BMG? SRS GIEZ)No combining stacks of ammo or healing sprays? (Fixed stacking now works!)Very low loot tables, crates need at least double the ammo/healing loot if not more.No jumping, climbing or swimming, cause these trained dinosaur hunters haven't learned that, and they can't even run very far.Any idiot can hack the game, at the very least, hosts need to be able to ban players from their servers, as one bad experience can ruin the game for people.Takeaway: Great fun with a few friends and easily worth 20 bucks.

number of helpful: 38 of 56 people (68%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 18, 2015
												If you don't like the hunter you probably wont like this game. That's just the way it is! Its not for the cod or bf2 fans. Its not run and gunning and running around without consequences. You have to play it like you are actually hunting or as close to that as you can get in a game. If you run you'll only spook the herbivores and call the predators. You have to place your shots. I see all these videos and almost 90% of the time they shoot for the head. You must go for those body shots, Like real hunting specifically the vitals besides dinos in this game have small brains and the chance of hitting them there is slim if at all. Hit em in the hart or the lungs and their gona go down if not immediately then within a few feet. Your the hunter and the hunted depending on the situation.Ive only been playing about 7 hours but I haven't died once yet, have no room left to carry anything and I have full camo because im careful and not in any rush. Ive never used the run meter once because you don't even need it if you play the way the game is intended. The metter is also for swinging handheld weapons so conserve it if you like to use it for running. The game is also very beautiful especially when everything is on high.With all this said, are there issues with the game? Of course. Is the game getting better? I think so and the immersion is really that good especially the thunder and lightening. Dinos do get stuck on cliffs, the t-rex has some issues and yes there is no swimming to name a few. Basically  I think that most of the complaints are from people who expect this game to be something it never was going to be. I also believe the games not the problem here its the people who play it, then complain that its not what THEY expected it to be.Like I said at the beginning of this review, If you like the hunter than you'll like the the hunter primal. If your looking for run and gun or a swimming simulator then go play something else because this isn't it nor will it ever be. Please also remember, when they say realistic that is also realative! My deffinition of what realistic is, of course is different than yours but as games go this one comes very close. If its not realistic enough for you then I suggest going outside and doing some real hunting!

number of helpful: 26 of 35 people (74%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've been avoiding early access recently, too many games on there that feel like a 2nd year computer games students university project floated on steam to make some undergraduate a little extra beer money, too often left buggy and unfinished, all that promise, and my cash, gone.Fortunately then, for theHunter: Primal that isnt the case here, and the game is in development by a studio that I've known and come to trust for a number of years now, who are commited to working with their community, and have a good solid history of regular updates and not abandoning their projects.Since I picked up the game on release yesterday, I've already seen 3 updates to the game pushed out, just off the back of tweaks the team realised were necessary from the early initial reports, which to me is suggestive of a good team.Built with the same avalanche engine that powers the games "older brother", theHunter: Primal builds on the back of a good solid hunting simulator and adds dinosaurs and survival to the mix.  Armed with nothing more than a bow, a handful of arrows and the clothes on your back, it's up to you to seek out better equipment and to try and survive.  As it's early access, the types of dinosaur are limited at the moment, with plans to add further animals as the development moves on.  Sure there's some kinks to be worked out, and some balancing issues to make the game enjoyable for the widest audience, but it's fully playable and highly enjoyable now.My favorite ingame experience so far?It was midnight, it was dark, and a badly timed trip had left me at the bottom of an open valley with trees on the slopes to either side of me.  A kilometer up ahead, the grasslands gave way to rock, and open country on the side of the islands volcano, a safe haven for me, if I could reach it, where I could hide amongst the crags with a clear view and wait out the dawn.But that was a kilometer away.  Much closer, the heavy footfalls and roar of a T-Rex reminded me I needed to keep moving.  Somewhere nearby the strange, laughter like chittering of a raptor let me know I was not alone.  Was I hunter, or prey?Carefully I moved through the undergrowth, hoping to sneak away, every sound seeming amplified, and fear running her icy fingers down my spine.  My character brushed up against something toxic and coughed, the noise so unexpected, caused me to freak out and jump out of my chair, before logging out and then laughing at myself for it.  Would I recommend the game to others? Absolutely.  If you enjoy hunting, dinosaurs or survival style games, then it's definitely worth a look.  As a caveat, however, this thing is in early access.  Expect a few bugs, balance issues and for things to change, but if you can live with that, it's really worth it.

number of helpful: 26 of 35 people (74%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've been avoiding early access recently, too many games on there that feel like a 2nd year computer games students university project floated on steam to make some undergraduate a little extra beer money, too often left buggy and unfinished, all that promise, and my cash, gone.Fortunately then, for theHunter: Primal that isnt the case here, and the game is in development by a studio that I've known and come to trust for a number of years now, who are commited to working with their community, and have a good solid history of regular updates and not abandoning their projects.Since I picked up the game on release yesterday, I've already seen 3 updates to the game pushed out, just off the back of tweaks the team realised were necessary from the early initial reports, which to me is suggestive of a good team.Built with the same avalanche engine that powers the games "older brother", theHunter: Primal builds on the back of a good solid hunting simulator and adds dinosaurs and survival to the mix.  Armed with nothing more than a bow, a handful of arrows and the clothes on your back, it's up to you to seek out better equipment and to try and survive.  As it's early access, the types of dinosaur are limited at the moment, with plans to add further animals as the development moves on.  Sure there's some kinks to be worked out, and some balancing issues to make the game enjoyable for the widest audience, but it's fully playable and highly enjoyable now.My favorite ingame experience so far?It was midnight, it was dark, and a badly timed trip had left me at the bottom of an open valley with trees on the slopes to either side of me.  A kilometer up ahead, the grasslands gave way to rock, and open country on the side of the islands volcano, a safe haven for me, if I could reach it, where I could hide amongst the crags with a clear view and wait out the dawn.But that was a kilometer away.  Much closer, the heavy footfalls and roar of a T-Rex reminded me I needed to keep moving.  Somewhere nearby the strange, laughter like chittering of a raptor let me know I was not alone.  Was I hunter, or prey?Carefully I moved through the undergrowth, hoping to sneak away, every sound seeming amplified, and fear running her icy fingers down my spine.  My character brushed up against something toxic and coughed, the noise so unexpected, caused me to freak out and jump out of my chair, before logging out and then laughing at myself for it.  Would I recommend the game to others? Absolutely.  If you enjoy hunting, dinosaurs or survival style games, then it's definitely worth a look.  As a caveat, however, this thing is in early access.  Expect a few bugs, balance issues and for things to change, but if you can live with that, it's really worth it.

number of helpful: 17 of 20 people (85%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
												I wish it had more then 5 dinos...but its never going to get more. Pros: World is massive.       - Sounds are fantastic, and scary. Gunfire sounds extremely well in this game. You can hear a fellow hunter over 800m away fire round after round as he is swarmed by raptors.  Raptors sound great and you can hear them close in on you.       -Terrain does what it should, the forest and different areas are very dense with foilage. So raptors can get real close to you without you seeing them. Stealth is a MAJOR part of gameplay.        -The community seems very friendly and willing to help you or talk with you. Almost every game ive joined ive left adding a friend on steam.  Hunting together is extremely fun and has saved my life a few times being in a larger group. In that same note, ive seen 2 t-rexs tear up a crowd of players in a valley i was attempting to join up with.      -The actual hunting can be really fun, as these dinosaurs can be tracked across the entire map, provided your skilled enough to keep their trail. It looks similiar to what i believe evolve is going to have for tracks. You can use dino calls, you scavenge for your gear like a dayz game, but your customizing and inventory is like an old school resident evil. Not much to it yet, there are scopes and different weapons but not many so far. 1 bow, 1 pistol, 2 rifles, 1 shotgun. different rounds for them liek the shotty has buck and slug.  The cons:     -DINO AI..(sometimes)......it needs patching but potential is there. A dinosaur can hear you, see you, and even track you. The raptors work in packs and can provide an issue because you do seem to get attacked by them from multpile directions. However, sometimes they charge past you, or walk right by you even tho your not hidden, they walk funny up hills, they sometimes aimlessly make wierd turns,The trex seems to have a few malfunctions aswell. Theres only 3 dinosaurs at the moment, with what i assume is ALOT more to come. SOmetimes dinosaurs stand there or get stuck and you can take them down easily. Other times, you get killed and never even saw it coming. Due to the small amount of species in the game thus far, their interactions from what i have seen are minimal. Smaller dinos run away from the big one. I would love to see the world become more alive in future updates. Maybe come over a hill and find a pack of raptors attacking a herd of herbavores or a single trex. I wish the raptors necks would turn to acknowldge you, the seem very rigid at times. other times its fine.ConclusionIts in alpha, and its already as solid as the carnivors games we had on pc in the early 2000s. Even with the bugs, that we all know alphas must go through, this game is a blast, and i do recommend it alsong as you dont get mad easily and can undertsand there will be problems as the game polishes out. I am having a blast though...I made this 1min 40 sec youtube video of the game just for fun,


YouTube™ Video: The hunter Pirmal Gamplay 

			Views: 557		

			I like this game so I made a trailer for it...i dont work for them, I just enjoy making movies.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												The game starts off with a single pioneer. You are basically forced to Primal Eden at gunpoint to help the Expansion Galaxies eradicate dinosaurs on the planet. If you die your close relatives volunteer to pick up where you left off.      Once on the planet for the first time, you have nothing more than a machete, settlers mate and clothes with no camo value at all. The game is an open world first-person shooter. You can find weapons or buy them if you are a high enough rank.        When you kill one of the  five dinosaurs on the planet. You use your settlers mate to harvest it. There are rare dinosaurs as well that drop special weapons that is later purchasable through the In game market when you die. From the harvests you gain G, that is used to purchase these weapons and equipment.       There are these settlements throughout Primal Eden that offer crates of weapons, equipment, and ammo. Certain settlements offer special weapons that are extremely expensive in the in-game market. Like the .50 cal rifle that is only found in one location and only spawns one per server.      Hosting a game is a bit difficult to setup. The game has a fair amount of bugs. You will have to open ports 42303 and 27015 in order to host. The game has no dedicated servers and what this means is your PC will become a server basically. You may still get the port error code message even if your ports are forwarded correctly. Your game may crash with other errors as well.      If you're into open world  survival horror first person shooters where you can hunt dinosaurs or other players. Then I highly recommend this game. It has its fair share of bugs, but the games direction is something unique and different

number of helpful: 24 of 33 people (73%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								My current review:Alright lets start with some things I see commonly come up:-There is no Micro-transactions, it is a one time purchase.-People seem to worry about it being abandoned like The Stomping Land. Avalanche Studios would have too much to lose if they ditched the game so do not see that happening. They are the ones responsible for the Just Cause games, I do not see them being willing to ditch a game to ruin sales of their other major games.-Yes there is bugs, it is early access.-Yes there is a lot of walking and patience required at some parts, this is hunting not a run and gun war game.So far I am quite enjoying this game even at it's beginning state, from the amazing visuals to hunting and being hunted by dinosaurs. There is currently 3 types of dinosaurs, 2 more planned during Early Access phase before release. You start off next to a pod in which you will receive a bow, arrows, and a map fragment, these items are quite weak (but can kill if used properly) and after exploring and surviving the dinosaur inhabitants you will stumble upon encampments and chests in which you can find loot. This can be anything from ammo, camo, health right up to guns.If you are not careful you could wind up in the jaws of a T-Rex or ambushed by a pack of Raptors. Stealth is your friend when hunting these creatures. T-Rexs are not really advisable to hunt alone as they are extremely tough to take down but with a group of fellow hunters you can take them on. Raptors can track you and even plan to flank you, plenty of times some will creep up on you without you even noticing keeping you on your toes a lot of the time.Your items go with you after you relog or switch servers, they are with you until you die at which point if you want your items back you will have to run back to where you died to reclaim your items if someone has not already looted your items. PVP is an option for servers to have as well.Some people do complain about the damage of the weapons against the dinosaurs but the thing is, they're dinosaurs, not thin skinned humans. They have thick skin, thick skulls and small brains, you want to aim for vital organs such as the lungs/heart for the maximum effectiveness. A well placed shot will take down a Raptor in one shot, a T-Rex can be taken down with several well placed shots although if you hit in a not so vulnerable area it will take a lot more to take the mighty beasts down. Animals if hurt enough will bleed out over time as well, so do not just automatically expect a fleeing animal survived. Even the mighty T-Rex may flee if hurt enough.I do not want to give much about the story of the game away, but there is a bit of a storyline behind it which you will discover while playing if you keep your eyes peeled out for such things.As for bugs, there is a few and I have crashed a few times but not enough for me to really complain. I could go on but this is already long. Overall if this is your type of game and do not mind supporting Early Access titles I would recommend it, if that does not sound like your thing, then wait it out.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2016
												Before you read too much into this, theHunter: Primal is a good game.However, the lack of updates and support from developers leaves this game feeling too empty and unrewarding for the player.The game currently features only 5 dinosaurs to hunt which isn't bad to start, but it get's old fast. This isn't helped by the fact that two of them behave very similarly, so you basically only have 4 unique dinos to hunt.Again, if the game were recieving constant updates this would be fine, but it's become pretty clear that this game is dead to them so they can work on more lucrative projects.The only bonus I guess would be that nothing is locked behind a pay wall like in theHunter. You get everything just for buying the game.That being said, the game itself is fun. It is an actual hunting simulator that you hunt dinosaurs in. Many people complain that it takes too long to get from A to B and that there isn't enough going on for most of the game. While things are spread VERY far appart and it can take a long time to walk to where you want to go... it's a hunting simulator.You're supposed to track things for a long time and have to walk long distances. It makes it feel more real for me. Just don't be expecting to run into the dino you're looking for after a few minutes or have giant, fast paced battles constantly.The game is very much: walk, track, walk, track, walk, track, shoot, track, walk, etc.Again, fine for some people, but not most.The main point of complaint would be lack of updates. The game does feel unfinished with only 5 dinos and no real reward system other than just buying better equipment. (Which is actually just annoying due to ammo and weight restrictions.)TL;DR: Amazing concept and execution hampered by the fact that the devs care more about money than this game. It's fun for a few hours but get's old fast. If you really want a realistic dino hunting game, buy this when it's on sale.

Early Access Review
								Day 4.Still hiding in the foliage, with 2 buckshot left.T Rex is out there somewhere, I can hear it... stomping around.Surrounded by Raptors, and If they find me, I will have to start shooting, but the T Rex will hear the shots...Just gotta wait it out a little bit longer...----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------If you're a fan of stealth mixed with survival / scavenging, then this game is perfect for you. T Rex's are perhaps the most terrifying thing you will ever try to run, hide, or even fight, as even hiding silently they can randomly find you within dense foliage, or inside a hollow tree trunk.There are a few problems with the inventory such as 1 buckshot round can take up the same amount of space as 5 buckshot rounds for example. It's like ammo is sorted out into individual groups, and once you run out of shots in an "ammo group", then you have to go into your inventory and place new group into the active slot, which would be tedious during a big fight. The game is very slow paced, as the player must allways take care when traveling from outpost to outpost. Sprinting randomly while traveling can leave the player in dire situations. I haven't been able to play multiplayer yet, but when I do I will update my early access review. Overall, the game has a "hardcore" feeling to it, and I have enjoyed the game so far.UPDATEStarted getting into multiplayer, but no PVP stuff (perhaps for the better). We managed to take down a T Rex after tracking it for about 20 minutes, as it was wounded and we were following blood trails.Video of the moment below.

Overall, I think I'm gonna be playing a lot more multiplayer now.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												In early access this game was actually quite good. The 3 dinosaurs, and duplicating glitches, allowed people to enjoy the game and have fun playing it. The ballence of rexs and the other dinosaurs were almost perfect, and if it released then, way more people would have played it. Then here comes the new updates, which ruined the game. First, the machette was added instead of the usual bow. The bow was good because, with experence, you could kill any dinosaur you wish. But now its almost impossible to hit or kill the flying Quetzalcoatlus or the rex due to the rex having its ability to stomp on you (even if you are ahead of it sometimes you can be "stomped"). What I also dislike was when the rex was in early alpha, you could dodge the rex, and could kill it with any type of weapon (even a bow if you had enough arrows). If would charge and you would dodge it. Simple as that. Then came the "improvements" with it. The first and fixed part was an increased spawn rate (which was bad, I will come back to this point in a minute), and secondly they "fixed" the rex running in one direction and can now (on a dime) spin and one shot you. Pair that with horrible hit markers and you got a n almost unkillable beast. The last and final straw was when they added the Quetzalcoatlus. They made the birds so common and so deadly (it would pick you up and drop you to your death) that most players stopped playing until the devs created a patch for them. The other "broken" thing about them is that it is almost impossible to "lead" you gun when they fly, and can only land a hit on them when they are in their attack charge. The worst part about these "birds" is that they can only be one shotted with a 700. gun (the 2nd best gun in the game) and even if you shoot it n the face with shotgun shells, it will shake off the damage and still kill you. Overall a unfinished and unpolished game. Needs major fixes for its community to not move onto another game.

dinosaurs to teleport, glitch, become invisible, respawn in the sky, kill with 1 hit and fly away to a random place, do a permanent moon walk still taking dammage and acting like they are alive making players waste bullets on them and many other bugs and glitches.-The map can dissapear or just don't show the icons of important places you already visited if you start the game, join a server, leave the server and joining another one without restarting the game.-Bodyparts from the player can dissapear mid-game making the cammo used in this slots be useless and literally non-existant from the game.-Poisonous plants can insta heal the 100% hp of the player-The AI still goes ape sh*t, the dinosaurs can't walk over rocks otherwhise they moon walk endlessly, they get stuck on trees, walls, etc, if 2 players shoot at the same time the dinosaur walks in circles, when they die while sprinting or leaping there is a small chance of the dinosaur flying away, dissapear or get assimilated to the floor making impossible a way to harvest the creature (if it flies away you can still find it at a random position of the entire map).-Awful banning system, if you ban someone from the server the player can still join with no problems no matter how many bans you already gave to the same person.-Constant bugs that involve: Sounds glitching, rain to randomly change (it'd be raining but the sound doesn't triggers and the hunting effects of rain doesn't apply, or it couldn't be raining but the effect would still apply or you could hear the rain but the graphics doesn't show it, etc.)-Splitting ammo into different stacks for friends now dissapears the ammo dropped.-Incomming sound from Rexes constantly glitching, getting cut in half or just comming out like a broken diologue-Broken hitboxes where at times hitting the same spot you get a heart shot and other times hitting in a completely different place you would still get the heart shot or hitting the tail you'll end up with a lung shot.And much more.They released the game as "full" when it even has more glitches than Skate 3 and with a even more broke AI than a Ubisoft game.I could buy Don't Starve Together and Besiege with the money spent on this game2/10 It's one of those games that should never leave the beta, proclaiming this as a "Full Game" is criminal

content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
												TheHunter: PRIMALOVERVIEWOK.... So theHunter: Primal is very very similar to theHunter (obviously) however the main difference are the fact that you cannot purchase anything and then equip them when you first start because it is not a hunting expedition, it's survival... However they have just added an in-game money system, where everytime you harvest a dino, you get money and when you level up, you unlock something in the shop, so when you die, you get taken to a shop where you can purchase weapons and whatnot before you spawn...But it's not like other survival games... you can't build stuff... you basically just gotta scavenge containers and bags and/or kill other players and take their stuff... if it's set to PVP of course...The graphics are a little better than the hunter in my opinion and who can ever forget the beautiful sunrise and sunset water colours... and choice scenery!As far as gameplay, the mechanics are buggy, but can only get better with time. The player movements are different from the Hunter the walking and running are faster, but they have introduced a sprint system which uses stamina and is extremely loud to attract dinosaurs. (Only use in emergency) The hunter mate (although called settler mate) works exactly the same way, spotting and tracking works the same but there isn’t tracking or spotting skill levels, and of course trophy shots and harvesting work the same way also. You don't get experience for weapon use in this game either... There is also a new tracking feature in which I really like... when you wound an animal and you track it's blood, it tells you in percentage how injured it is... for eg.... after shooting a T-Rex 6 times with a shotgun, after scanning it's blood it told me that it had 45-60% health left and the next time I shot it once... it said 30-48% (as well as body/intestine shot etc)THE GOOD- Great graphics - Excellent immersion (especially when the t-rex is nearby or when a raptor knows you're there and he/she calls out to the pack to help look for you)- Cool map with central volcano (no dinosaur game is complete without a volcano to set the mood)- Has major potential for many wonderful things- No pay to win, no money at all (except in-game currency from harvesting)- Injury percentage for prey- When you die, you can retrieve your goods from your old backpack... as long as no-one else has pillaged it!!- Thunderstorms :D- Mean looking dinosaursTHE BAD- Lots of gameplay bugs and a rushed full release from Early Access- Only five dinosaurs... T-Rex, Utahraptors, Triceratops, Velociraptors and Quetzalcoatlus (Dino-birds)- Scavenging gets boring and old really quickly - needs traditional ‘the Hunter’ mode- Controls are very stiff and sometimes sluggish- Bad framerates in high detailed areas such as swamps and dense jungle regions- Faulty hit register, (shoot the 6,000kg T-Rex in the heart with a .700 while it's standing still and it registers as only a body hit, where sometimes I can drop a 10,000kg Triceratops on the run with one .308 round to the heart, where the bullet hole is on the leg... Can be quite frustrating at times... as you die from not dropping them or you run out of ammo...- Quetzalcoatlus seem to be able to swoop through hilly terrain and through metal spikes and grab you, even though you shot them in the head...- Sound is a little buggy crossing from biome to biome- The Quetzalcoatlus, although remarkable are very annoying and frustrating to deal with at times...WHAT IT NEEDS- Need to be able to craft something, to build defences to stand a chance killing dinosaurs without dying- Needs more dinosaur species (especially herbivores) and less of the current ones for a nice balanced game- Need to see the Dinosaurs attacking each other... raptors attacking T-rex and Triceratops, Velociraptors getting taken by Quetzalcoatlus and the traditional T-Rex versus triceratops battle...- Maybe a 4 wheeler would be good as usually the game spawns you on the other side of the map as your friends- The T-rex needs to have a bigger roar like on Jurassic Park... to really make your hairs stand on end.- A traditional ‘the Hunter’ mode, to create expeditions instead of scrounging around...VERDICTOverall I give this game a 6.5/10, well worth $15 - $20 AUD MAX... but knowing the developers... they did such an awesome job with ‘the Hunter’... So I expect the same with this... So if you like the Hunter I recommend getting ‘the Hunter: Primal’, especially since Dinosaurs will soon be ruling Hollywood again, it's nice to finally see a switch from zombie survival for once.Also a funny thing... when you find some T-Rex poo, you'll notice it has human arms and some skulls in it... fkn hilarious!! Even funnier than that Jurassic Park satellite phone scene!!

Posted: November 26, 2016
												I enjoyed this game, it had a lot of potential back then...so much so in fact that I put some time and effort in answering a survey the devs sent out over a year ago. There were actually quite a lot of us who helped the devs identify all the current gameplay issues, and give them some feedback on how we who like the game to progress moving forward. The devs had made it well clear that they were prepared to put in the effort into creating new content for the game, and the community and the players believed them and supported them.A little over a year later (after completing the survey), we finally hear back from the dev team with a laughable patch, stating the game is now in full release (with the price heavily knocked down).Needless to say we all know what that means. The dev team has abandoned development on this game and has run away with the early access money from the players and most importantly, they did not deliver on their promise to the whole community.I must say I'm baffled that Steam allows these developers to get away with charging full price on a game and failing to deliver: it’s a lack of respect on both the players and on steams’ standards.Most importantly, it teaches us that we should never purchase a game in early access. Lesson learned then. Do not purchase this game.

												After collecting 100% of the Steam achievements in a total of 240 hours of gameplay I can state that theHunter: Primal is a crappy and disapointing game. Here is my explanation why: I was already familiair with the hunting simulator theHunter and the announcement of theHunter: Primal got my interest in 2014. I bloody loved the game when it got available for early access and it was such a blast to hunt dinosaurs, explore the map, trying to find gear with all kinds of people from all over the world. And the best things was that there only was more to come! Or was there...The game got fully released with only a couple of more dinosaur species, dinosaur variants and weapons with the occasional bug fixes. Today it still feels like it is in early access and unfinished. After all I can conclude that the developers did a cashgrab with this game and then totally abandoned it. Such a shame, because the game had so much potential and an active community. Sadly, the pricedrop indicated to me at least that it is not going to be any better soon. I do not recommend this game, the customer is being poorly treated.Positive points:+ Graphics+ Large Map+ Hitting vital organs matters+ Multiplayer can be a lot funNegative points:- Lack of overall content- Clunky controlls- Dinosaur AI tends to be annoying- Framedrops in certain areas- Game crashes

content:
Posted: April 26, 2015
												For those dinosaur fanactics out there, those who enjoyed  carnivores 1 & 2. And any other hunting sim, your welcome to come try theHunter Primal. I have over 400 hours in this game, by far one of my personal favorites among my group of games. Also best played with friends. Going to lay the line out flat now so you guys know the cons before anything else in this game.1. It's a survival/hunting game, so you have to scanvenge for gear and level for better gear. This depends on your forte in gaming, but there is no crafting in this game. So minecrafters......stay out.2. Still a few bugs to do with in game, but no need to fear. The devs have cleaned this game quite a bit since early access and its smooth and clean. so far anyway :D3. if you faint of heart and you don't have a good set of headphones, i suggest you get them otherwise you'll be ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ your pants every 5 mins at the start of your first day alone :P good luck!Now the pros of this game1. 5 dinosaur species, Trex, 2 sets of raptors, Velociraptor and Utahraptor <(I'm from jurassic park). and the famous triceratops and lastly the quatzocoatlutus. Each animal is extremely unique and can be very dangerous to you if you dont know whats up, read up your guides and even then, you won't be prepared. 2. Buddies, amazing that you have em. With the games Co-op/pvp servers which you can create on your own simply opening a port in your router. Now you have friends to play with and dont forget steam voice chat! communcation is key when hunting a rex. Or maybe you get caught in a ravine and mashed by 30 raptors :P3. Very expansive world, there isnt anywhere on this map you can't travel and mutliple biomes to explore. From the plains to the volcano it doesnt get any better then this. I have personally walked the map a few times now, and it roughly takes up to 8 hours if not more to cover it all. Have fun!4. Graphics are gorgeous even on a lower power PC. The animals look amazing, between the butterflys to the leaves falling the game doesnt get any better than that.Now you now the pros and cons and a whole 30 bucks and look what it got me :P 400 hours of good ole fashioned fun so please join the game and our community. The more support this game gets the more dinos it may or may not have to weapons etc. And think of you and your buddies getting together to go hunt a rex for that big trophy only to be eaten! Its a blast and it gets my 5 out 5 stars. Good luck out in the field folks!

												DON'T LET THE POSITIVE REVIEWS FOOL YOU! MOST OF THOSE WERE WRITTEN BY PEOPLE DURING THE GAME'S EARLY ACCESS STAGE. WHICH THE DEVS ARE CONVENIENTLY INCLUDING WITH THE GAMES FULL RELEASE!Major network issues with the game. To this day a lot of people still have trouble hosting, even after forwarding the correct ports, which they shouldn't have to do in the first place!This game was more fun in its EA stage than it is right now. They released it prematurely without ironing out all the bugs. The dino populations and AI are still a mess. There are glitches o' plenty (Birds grabbing you even though you're clearly out of reach, Rexes biting through walls etc.) Gameplay is missing basic fundamentals. (No jump ability, Crippled Aim Down Site/Slow movement while aiming, inadequate stamina, etc.)No dedicated servers. (official or player hosted)No control for the Game host. (weather control, selective dino species, gear theft -other players can take your gear in the PVE environment-)There are no interactions between the Dinos. No Bull Trikes battling each other. No raptors ganging up on Trikes. No rexes eating raptors. Boasting "most realistic" and then delivering this as a final product? You gotta be kidding me...At one point I loved where this game was going. At this point I cannot recommend it.I really hope they make some drastic changes soon. I'd like to enjoy this game again sometime.And for the dumba$$es rejecting this review even though all I've done is pointed out facts. If you don't agree with facts maybe consider jumping on the scientology bandwaggon. You'd fit right in there!Here's a video I made supporting some of my claims. Just to show that some of these A$$clowns rejecting this review have no idea what a good functioning game is.

												While theHunter: Primal was an interesting idea and new take on theHunter I think that the potential is wasted. Early Access Review
I think this should be called "TheHunted".Great game! Although still in Early Access, I think this game is oozing with potential, a few things will need to be changed and added, such as sorting out the spawnzones, adding more dinosaurs and changing how frequent those darn raptors are, but all in due time! Although this version has more to do with Survival, it is still much like the original TheHunter, as this game is very strategic and also very entertaining, intense and immersive once you get going! (especially on multi player).This is how my gameplay has been so far: 1st life: Spawned into the world, only to find myself instantly surrounded by Utahraptors, I majestically pulled out my bow and managed to kill 4 of the little buggers, only to be killed by a 5th one that caught me off guard... "Clever girl...".2nd life: Spawned to hear more Utahraptors; I ran before obtaining a bow and died instantly.3rd life: Spawned in a clearing, only to hear a loud, booming roar behind me. Before I had the chance to turn around: I got T-REKT.4th life: managed to crawl my way out of danger and eventually found a basic rifle.... TheHunted had become TheHunter, this is what it's all about - time to get my revenge!

content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												Let's keep it simple.Graphics: 9/10Graphics here are nice and solid for the genre.  It won't make you wet yourself with glee but it's nice and clean.  No painful visual issues, at all.  Whoever did the lighting work did an excellent job.Controls: 8/10The controls are a bit unwieldy.  I adjusted the keyboard settings and it became quite comfortable though.  (Tip: The grave accent key to the left of the 1 is an excellent key to reassign something to for this one)Pacing: 5/10I found the pacing very odd.  I understand that it is an in dev game but there is oddly little to do.  Maybe more will come later but for those considering buying let me simplify it.  Right now, your life will consist of first hiding and crawling around on your belly to avoid scaly monsters.  Then, if you are very very lucky, you will get a weapon and it becomes your job to stop hiding and hunt them.    There are no other activities, strictly speaking, as far as I can tell.  You decide if that's fun for you.Price: 3/10While I definitely see the possibility for this game to become good I would say, 'Save your money for a bit.'  This either will drop in price or become worth the current one.  If you have limited gaming funds, try something else.  It is still too uncertain to say where this one will go.

												     This game HAD good potential... still does if the developers will actually come back to this game to fix some issues, provide support and add more content. My experience with support so far is terrible. I sent them an email about this error code (250477278) that has been keeping me from even starting the game since I couldn't find a fix for it in the forums, it took 12 days for anyone to reply back. They COULD HAVE just told me what this error meant or if they even knew what it meant in the first reply but for some reason didn't and just said "sorry for the delay. Your ticket was found in our spam folder due to the ammount of time passed, if the issue hasn't been resolved or solution found please respond and we will look into it ASAP..."      I replied back the very next day telling them the issue still hasn't been resolved yet and asked them if they could tell me what the error code means... it's been another 8 days and still no reply from them even letting me know if they have seen the message, are working on this issue or not... so far about an hour of my time on record for this game has been me sitting in the launcher screen trying to see if it's a graphics setting I have set causing these issues but have had no success and I have even tried reinstalling the game. It really does feel like the developers just took the money and ran so in this current state I have to advise against buying this game, because if something breaks it doesnt look like the developers are going to care too much.

Post Early Access Update!I've got to say, with all of the constant bug fixing Avalanche has done to this game alone, you'd be crazy not to buy this game. Not to mention all of the great additions they've managed to add on the way. I am also very happy to see the 20% off discount with the game's full release. Grab this great game, folks.Early Access ReviewThis game looks like it has GREAT potential in the near future, as long as the developers continue to patch and update the current alpha version. As it stands I would have to recommend this game as long as updates are continuously released and good changes are made.Of course, it is a 50/50 when purchasing a game this early in alpha stages. THERE ARE BUGS! Keep this in mind.PROS:- Great optimization- Realistic dino sounds. You can hear them a mile away.- Good sound quality.- Higher than average graphics. (I have screenshots on my profile w/high settings.)- Beautiful scenery.CONS:- Unstable and strange AI. Sometimes dinos walk over you, sometimes they chase you for miles.- The dreaded "Player Timing Out Message" whenever someone leaves a server.- Random crashing (Has gotten better with patches)All of these things are subject to change, as the game is in alpha!

Also, this game should be in early access as it has a relatively pathetic amount of content, although even in it's current state the game is very immersive.It seems like they'll be including a DLC in recent days. I think that's amazing, even though you could call this ''robbery'' since the game is still nowhere near finished I think the devs just need more motivation and this could still be one of the best dinosaur games ever to be released. Since most of you are not going to be reading all this I'll just get straight to the pros and cons of this game.Pros-Beautiful and large world-Plenty of potential-Extremely immersiveCons-Dinosaurs are way underpowered, especially utahraptor and velociraptor. If you're looking for a horror game with dinosaurs in it, this isn't your best choice-Huge lack of dinosaur species-No workshop supportNow, would I recommend this game in it's current state? Well that really depends on what you are looking for when buying this game. If you want to experience the dinosaurs living in their natural environment and experience the prehistoric-like ambience you will most likely love this game, even in it's current state. But if you aren't interested in this, and you want this game just to hunt the dinosaurs I would not recommend this game at the moment since there are only a few dinosaur species to hunt.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												Ok, so let me start by saying I do enjoy this game a lot, but I (and im sure many others) would like it a lot better if there were more dino's and possibly even more weapons, but I'm not too fussed about it.GAMEPLAYtheHunter: Primal is a hunting game. So don't go into it expecting to be able to kill the dino's, cook their meat and eat it, or be able to build a shelter. This game is a survival game, but not in the sense like the forest or stranded deep. I haven't played the normal theHunter game so I'm not sure if this game has the same mechanics, but i do enjoy the tracking system, and the ability to use stealth to your advantage to either hunt or get away from a dino. The game has no plot or storyline which does make it a bit boring for those people who expect to have an overall mission. 8/10 for gameplay.THE MAPThe world that this game is set on is visually stunning (if you have a decent computer) and is actually really big, so you can spend a lot of hours just navigating your way around the map and discovering the different environments which in itself is enjoyable. The addition of settlements is great because they can provide players with a goal or shelter. 10/10 for the map.MULTIPLAYERThis game is pretty much just a multiplayer game. There is no point even bothering to play singleplayer because you will die. I am yet to play on a PvP server because personally I find it more enjoyable to hunt with others, not against them. This game is meant for friends to actually play together and take down a rex, which is why you can buy it in a 4-pack. You will find people even in PvE servers that will backstab you and take your stuff, but you will find even more people that will help you survive if you are a new player ( I have helped multiple new player get to a settlement and get some gear). 8/10 for multiplayer.DINO AI, SPAWNRATE AND HITBOXESOk, so this is defeniatly the biggest issue that the game has. The AI for most of the dino's is really annoying and is kinda dumb (they are working on improving this though). The spawnrate of dino's is actually reasonably good at the moment, and pretty much all old players will know of the problems created by some updates (When they increased the rex spawn rate so you couldn't walk through a field without seeing 10 rexes, and the Quetz update where you couldn't walk though a field without being dropped to your death). The hitboxes at the moment are terrible and gotta be fixed. I have been picked up by quetz's when i am standing 10 feet on either side of it, and bitten by Utahraptors even when I sidestep them. 6/10 for the AI, spawnrate and hitboxesOVERALL VERDICTOverall, i would defeniatly recommend this game for people looking for a game which provides a good teamwork experience, and are looking to make friends while hunting dino's (it's a win-win if you ask me). I would tell people that want a game where they can just jump in and start spraying dino's to look somewhere else.7/10 rating for the whole game.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2016
												Considering all of the negative reviews I've seen, I didn't go into this expecting much. Yet, maybe that's why I came out of it pleasantly surprised at the quite enjoyable game play. It's similar to theHunter, which is also made by the same people, in the way it plays. You follow tracks or dinosaur sounds to find them, then shoot them, and have to track them down to claim your prize. However, this being dinosaurs, it doesn't tend to go that smoothly.I will admit I've encountered the bug or two, having been launched into the air by a raptor who took a bite out of my face before running away, the stand button suddenly not working as I'm having my groin ravaged or watching as raptors furiously run into a wall as they attempt to flee from me after I've shot them.However, despite all this. It's fun, and can be quite exhilarating when you suddenly find yourself smashed into by a Quetz for the first time or hear the footsteps of a T-Rex that's now dangerously close, having to fall to the floor and hold your breath in the hopes it will pass you by.

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												I was very, very surprised to see that this game was released to soon after entering early access. A name like Avalanche Studios carries weight with me, and that's mostly the reason I bought this game a few days after it came out on early access. It didn't have much content, but it was in early access, so I has expecting that they'd add more. I was so very much hoping that I'd able to return to this game after a few months of development. I was wrong. First of all, this is not a bad game. It's a good game, don't get me wrong. The graphics are amazing, the sound design is probably the best of any game I've ever played, the dinosaurs are well designed and the terrain is well crafted. The world is massive and will take you at least an hour to walk from one side to the other on foot. With that being said, mechanically, this game is sound, more or less. The new flying dinos broke the game with their bugs, (thankfully, the worst one was fixed) they fly through terrain, are sometimes impossible to see or hear, and make you unable to reclaim your gear after you become dino-chow. There are a few more bugs related to the dinosaurs, but thankfully I've never encountered a crash.The game (to my knowledge) advertised this to be a survival game, but, don't be fooled: there is anything that remotely has to do with the "survival" genre that we've come to know and love within games like The Forest and Stranded Deep. The only type of "survival" to be found here is the kind where you avoid not being killed. This IS "survival", per se, as surviving literally means "not dying", but hey, semantics. I was really looking forward to the kind of survival that I thought was being advertised, and I suppose that it could be said that it was my misinterpretation of what I read that lead to my disappointment. I was so excited to make a base, look for food, water and weapons, make medicines and then go hunting for some large extraterrestrial lizards. (Yes, in case you didn't know, this game takes place on an alien planet.) I do know for sure that this game labels itself as "realistic". This is probably where my misconception originated from:"Hunt - Explore - Survive The most realistic prehistoric survival game ever created." theHunter: Primal, 2014. There's nothing realistic about hunting dinosaurs on an alien planet. Trust me. I know my♥♥♥♥♥♥ But do I care about that? No, of course not. I get to hunt dinosaurs realistically, of course. All sillyness aside, and to summarize what I've just said, I'm sad I can't have a real dino-hunting/survival game. This leads me to me largest and most bitter gripe with this game: there's no content. There's nothing. Literally. Well, not literally... there's a few gigs of space being taken up by this on my C: drive, but it's substance is lacking quite a lot. There are a total of 5 dinosaurs to hunt. 5 dinosaurs in total.This is a dinosaur hunting game with only 5 dinosaurs. Why? There are only a few weapons too. These are what I can think of: Magnum, Rifle, Shotgun, .50 cal Sniper Rifle, Machete, Bow. The bow is REALLY buggy too, and I've never found the .50 cal Sniper Rifle. While there are some cool attachments you can put on your weapons, there is no excusing the lack of content here. Sure the world is big, but what good is it if there's nothing to do. The game is thirsty, it's STARVING, its emaciated; just begging---"Please, please, give me sustenance! Food, water!" And we're here, kneeling beside this sad mess of skin and bones, screaming, "Yes! Please! Feed it, FEED IT! WE BEG OF YOU!"The developer answered our cries for more content by saying, "Hmm... maybe. If it sold more copies, we might."(I can provide a link to the discussion thread where a dev said this, if anyone wants it. Assuming they don't delete it, of course. The thread is titled "Post-release heads up.)Uhh. I paid $20 dollars for this game. For some unimaginable reason, the devs think that the small, bare-bones amount of content they added within the few short months of early access somehow, and unexplainably, warrented a 50% increase to the price of the game. It's insulting, really. I never would have bought this game in early access if I knew that they wouldn't add anything to it. That's the risk we take when we buy early access games and technically it is our fault for making a bad purchase, but still, it makes me feel sh*tty. Something needs to be done about early access and fast, otherwise, I'm probably never going to buy early access again. The sheer amount of failures of games that come out of that proverbial cesspool too early, or in this case, looking like a actor/actress who overdid the pea soup diet for their first appearance at the Academy Awards is staggering. To conclude, this game is a massive disappointment and a massive waste of potential, one of the largest for me in recent memory. Do youself and your loved ones a favor and stay away from this thing. I might have expected this sort of thing from Expansive Worlds, but not Avalanche. Why Avalanche, why! I'm not not sure what kind of role they played in developing this game, but just the fact alone that they had anything to do with this game makes me want to give Just Cause 3 a miss.

content:
Posted: March 25
												I wouldn't call this a hunting game, since you will most likely spend very little time actually hunting.Hunting in this game is more of a brief side challenge to the main game, which is slowly walking around a giant map trying not to die while you find tools just to get started.The game actually has a giant and varied map, which is pretty, even if it gets a bit blocky in some areas. The downside of having a huge map however is that there is NO FAST TRAVEL. Expect to slowly walk (and briefly run) through a mostly empty map for your entire playthrough. Join a friends server? You may end up having to walk across the entire map to reach them upon joining, alone with no items. Unfortunately, even though you are given a good mapping tool, you will rarely ever be able to make the most of it.The game is basically 100% ironman mode. On death you lose ALL map data, ALL weapons, and ALL equipment.Then you will be transported quite a distance away from your body, with a blank map and a machete. If you're lucky, you MIGHT be able to make it to your body and recover your items (but not map) without dying again to whatever killed you in the first place, be it Trex, or incredibly steep cliffs that you always seem to spawn at the bottom of.This game also doesn't have a single player mode, the closest thing being a private passworded server.I HIGHLY recommend that if you choose to play this, you only play it with a group of friends who are also REALLY into walking/hunting games. You can try looking for public online games, but you may have issues finding someone who speaks your language to hunt with.While you sort of level up from killing dinos, the only thing it really affects is what items you can buy after each death, assuming you have any credits to do so.If you are looking for a fun, easy to get into hunting game, DO NOT PLAY THIS.

number of helpful: 11 of 15 people (73%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												I got this game in a bundle, but it would still be well worth $10.It has a top notch immersive environment with a full day/night cycle as well as weather effects. The sound design is absolutely amazing and you will feel yourself in a pristine island. The calls of dinosaurs in the distance, or the rustling of leaves in the foliage, or the ominous steady stomps from T-rexes are just a few of the environmental surround that you will experience.There are weapon crates scattered all over the island, but these are still a bit scarce. This is the first game to actually give me a survival-feel that are absent in most open world survival/apocalypse games. The dinosaurs are scarce too, or will feel like it until you learn to notice footprints and the small darting movements from the corner of your eyes in thick jungles.Two negatives I want to address. The island is freaking big but you travel really slow. That does add immersion but also adds tediousness. I recommend getting a trainer that gives unlimited sprint (but even that is slow).The second is that the devs abandoned the game. So what you experience the first 10 hours will probably be just about everything the game has to offer in terms of novelty.I would still recommend it, if you're into an immersive game.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Editted 9 MarchSo i played this game for a long while now. I realy like the game and its dinosaurs. Yes they have feathers wich means the developers didnt fall into the jurassic park trap and made all the dino's like the movies. DINOSAURSThe game now has 4 dino's the Tyranosaurus Rex the Triceratops the Utah Raptor wich is the raptor they SHOULD've used in jurassic park and the Velociraptor. I like the modelling of the dino's and the behaviour off them is great. I realy Like the new AI Utahraptors are a lot more dangerous and can instakill if you give them the chance. The Velociraptors are a nice species that is realy hard to see in fiolage and can be a real thread if you are almost out of ammo. It gives a more scary feeling to the game wich is always good.Rexes are smarter too and use their senses more like smell and hearing. So you should keep your distance without the proper ammo.Triceratops should still attack more 1 out of 10 attacks at the moment and this isnt enough I think it should be if you shoot badly it should attack you.GAME OVERALLI like this game a lot, this is the game i was looking for, for about 10 years now. The survival and hunting combo is great. Many people are talking about crafting etc but i dont like this. I like it how it is now but i would like some missions. Maybe some sort of campaign in single player and one seperate for multiplayer. Like bring a package there or hunt these animals maybe give some rexes names like in the logs. ( big chop etc...) Yes i know about the steam achievements but I dont think this will keep me busy. Leveling is nice and if you choose you can buy some ammo or even weapons and camo in the shop but only when you die. I first thought it to be a bit lame but now I understand that it is to give you a headstart and I like it. It means that you still have to loot after you bought things when you run out.PVE or PVPWell i only played PVE and I realy like the fact of hunting together. Only one thing could be added in PVE and thats locked bags so if you die nobody can steal your stuff. For that they need to do PVP.WEAPONSBow - Its the first weapon you get on primal eden. Its not very powerfull so you have to get close range with dinosaurs and aim very well. I wouldnt advice using it on a rex..44 handgun - Nice little handgun for using on the velociraptors and utahraptors although its not strong enough for rex you can kill a trice with it if you aim it right.Shotgun - My second favorite weapon its a very good weapon against all dino's when you learn how to use it. I have killed many rexes with it close range and against large utah raptor packs its realy the only option to get out off it alive. It has 2 kinds of bullets Buck wich spreads and Slug wich is a large solid bullet i leave it up to you to find out wich is best for what..308 Marksman Rifle - My favorite weapon I use it for all dino's although its very very hard to kill a rex with it because a rex doesnt take much damage from it long range. I think this is unrealistic though and if it becomes more powerfull over long ranges I would use it against rexes aswell.Oh yeah and it has a scope maybe thats why I like it so much :)..700 Dual Barrel Rifle - It is the strongest weapon available in the game but weirdly I dont like it very much. It is a heavy rifle and it can kill a rex in 1 - 4 shots if aimed properly.Because you have limited inventory space you can only take 2 big weapons and 1 little weapon. I choose the shotgun and .308 every single time so I can cary enough ammo for both.DEVELOPERSWel i heard some horror story's about developers before. (ehum stomping lands...) But i think we can trust this lot, they always answer when they can and they keep fixing bugs and adding stuff.I realy like what im seeing here keep it up ;).CONCLUSIONFor an early acces game i can only say its great. The developers keep bussy. Its a nice sometimes even enslaving game. If you add ingame missions for me and my mates I would be more than happy.If I have to give this game a grade I would give it 8 out of 10 maybe it gets to 10 out of 10 when its ready ;).I would recomment this game to people who like hunting games or shooting games where you have to sneak a lot. And ofcourse people who like dino's. But its not a silly game in wich you cant die by casual playing so keep that in mind.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								To be honest, I can't compare it to DayZ and/or Rust because it falls into a different category of survival. There is no crafting, hunger etc. (thank god). It gets it's map design concepts from previous dinosaur games such as Turok and Jurassic: The hunted and improves upon them greatly. You can get lost in the atmosphere and your imagination can run rampant. Was that a dinosaur I just heard? Or was my imagination playing tricks on me again? The Pros:Tense and Foreboding atmosphereOutstanding map designAmazing SoundtrackNo in-game purchases Smart A.I.MultiplayerThe Cons: Multiplayer is buggy (It's early access, what did you expect?)Only 3 dinosaurs to hunt currentlyWalking is a little slowA.I. pathing is weird around certain obstaclesI only played a few hours so far in singleplayer and already I have had my fair share of memorable moments. I defiantly have high hopes for this game so far. I highly recommend this game if you want to play a serious dinosaur survival game.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2016
												CONS: You have to work really hard to be able to buy weapons, as you start the game with nothing. Once you  buy them, you only keep them for one game session. After that, they will not spawn in your pod, but rather some distance away maybe easy to get to, maybe not.. The game is also very slow pace. Running and sometimes even walking is out of the question: you will probably lure something hostile and die unless you sneak.Also, don't be surprised if you lose everything because of the game crashing or losing connection to the server. The player is treated as if they died and never recovered the gear, so you will lose everything if you lose connection.PROS: Know that this game is difficult and is sort of unorthodox in some ways, like how weapons are spawned and that you start with nothing. Pretty much everything about the environment is hostile, even the plants poison you. If you want just a hunting game, I would suggest theHunter rather than theHunter Primal.That being said, this game is very good. It is beleivable, yet not overly complex, so the behavior of the predators and how to use the environment become predictable with practice. This is really not so much a hunting game, especially if being played solo, but rather a survival game. Once you're able to buy or find an arsenal of powerful weapons you can finally begin to act like a top predator. Most of the begining hours will be spent finding weapons and killing smaller game. Run from the T Rex until you know you can kill it. Honestly, you can easily be killed by almost all of the dinos, even the flying ones, which look so mediocre.
